comment:
嫌なら辞めれば、というコメントは筋違い。海外赴任は期間限定だから数年で日本の元の環境に戻る。だから辞める人なんていない。
話してる内容が共感されてない部分もあるみたいだけど、そもそも海外で家族や友人と離れて、限られた日本人の狭いコミュニティの中で朝から晩まで過ごし、下手したら土日も一緒にゴルフするような生活というのは非常にストレスフルなもので、経験者しかわからないのだと思う。

ただ、日本に帰ったときに箔が付くので転職市場でかなり有利になりますよ！

response_to: 【これが現実】エリート駐在員にストレスを吐き出してもらった結果…【シンガポール】
comment:
私の夫は出張者を食事だけでなく、ゴルフにも連れて行ってました。セントサでゴルフをすれば、また機嫌良く出張に来てくれると思うからです。本人曰く、俺は小使いさんから社長までやってる、とよく言ってました。
仕事ができて、気が利き、ローカルの人と付き合うのも得意、帰宅が11:00〜2:00でも7時前には出勤、週末はゴルフ。ゴルフ大好き、車も大好き、そういう人には会社は殆ど何でも払ってくれます。夫は英語は得意ではなかったけど、駐在員最適人間でした。でもこんな生活を長く続けると、怖い病気が待っています。ついでに言うと、全く健康無視だったからできたんだと思う。

response_to: 【これが現実】エリート駐在員にストレスを吐き出してもらった結果…【シンガポール】
comment:
私もシンガポールとマレーシアに駐在経験があるので、興味深く聞かせて頂きました。私も大変なことやいやなことがたくさんありましたが、トータルで見てハッピーな駐在だったと思っています。
ネガティブな気持ちで駐在するのもポジティブな気持ちで駐在するのも本人次第でしょう。

response_to: Visiting The Last Surviving Village in Singapore | Kampong Lorong Buangkok🇸🇬
comment: Yes, Kampong Buangkok is one of the last remaining villages in Singapore, 50 years ago, many parts of the island had similar villages but on a much bigger scale. Then, the kampongs were self-contained,  with shops, restaurants, markets, cinemas, police station, post office and community centers. Some of the villagers were farmers, planting vegetables and fruit trees, and there are still pig farms and chicken farms. Now we can only have a glimpse of what Singapore was like by wandering around Kampong Buangkok or Pulau Ubin. Fascinating how Singapore had changed within the last 50 years.

response_to: Visiting The Last Surviving Village in Singapore | Kampong Lorong Buangkok🇸🇬
comment: シンガポール最後のカンポンとは貴重な場所ですねー。昔はブキティマ周辺にも同様の集落が点在していたはずですが、今や跡形もなく開発されてしまいました・・・。かつて住んでいた家の正面にもカンポンが広がっており、そこに生えているランブータンの木から実を採ってもらったり、我が家のゲートをくぐって庭に入って来るニワトリを追い回して遊ぶのが日常でした。家事を手伝ってもらっていたメイドさんもそのカンポン住まいで、木がうっそうと茂った森の中を手を引かれ、映像にもあったようなトタン屋根を葺いた家に連れて行ってもらい、そこで昼食をご馳走になったりしていました。。私の幼少期の終わりと共になくなった古き良きシンガポールです。

comment:
カナダ在住です。
日本はほんとサービス、外食安すぎますよねw

こっちはラーメン一杯チップ入れたら普通に2000円ぐらいしますし、日本のスーパー、コンビニにあるものも全部安すぎてビビります。結局良いサービスに高いお金を払う文化がないと安売り競争で衰退してしまうのかなぁなんて思いますが、とかく日本＝安いは間違いないですねー。

response_to: 外国人が連想する「日本」の本当のイメージとは？海外に20年住んだ僕が教える

日本スゴイ系の番組は、国民のジニ係数を下げるのが目的っぽいですね。
昔は日本はダメ日本はダメ、でしたが今や真逆の報道。しかしテクノロジーや、ゲームすら落ちぶれました。
UIホントに悪いですよね日本。駅で切符買うのすら、上を見ないと買えない国です。わりと終わってます。

response_to: 外国人が連想する「日本」の本当のイメージとは？海外に20年住んだ僕が教える
comment: ビックリしました、いつもの挨拶と違ってテンション上がってますね。何か悪い物でも食べましたか？いゃ〜本当言われる通りですよね、外国から見た日本はまさにその通りって感じです。テクノロジーの進化は何処の国にも有り、いつまでも日本が1番で有り続けるのは難しいことかも知れませんね。日本人は生真面目ですが、頭が堅いのか、何かに固執してしまう所はあるのでね。でも、新しい物ばかりでなく古い物も大切にする所が日本の良い所だとおもいます。それが文化の継承になり独自の日本を生み出して、それに魅了された外国の方達が観光で来てくれる。そこでお客様に対する優しさで有りおもてなし文化の相乗効果が生きてくるのだと思います。それにジブさんが外国から見て感じた事を発信して下さってるので日本の池の中のカワズになら無い様に気付かせて貰えますもんね。ありがとございます。あれ？なんかいつもと違う真面目なコメントしてしまった。💦最初の挨拶で感が狂ってしまった。早く寝ます。

response_to: Hawkers After the Lock Down | Old Airport Road Food Centre, Singapore
comment: I think you have discovered that Singapore really seems like just one big restaurant!  Maybe all of South East Asia like this?  When I was based in NYC I had two assistants that were from Thailand.  We used to poke fun at them for how food-centric they were.  They would start talking about lunch around 10:00am.  Sometimes I would go looking for a stapler or scotch tape and open up a drawer at their desk and it would be like a small 7/11.  Sauces/spices/dried snacks/plastic forks/napkins.  The special treat was when they would sometimes cook lunch for all of us....so GOOD.

response_to: I Was Challenged By My Viewer… And This Is The Outcome🥊😤
comment: Dont be so bad "lah" for a foot down statement. Don't be so bad "leh" when connecting emotionally trying to convince the person not to be bad. Dont be so bad "ah" when making sure the person doesn't act badly. Dont be so bad "hor" when you know the person will act badly so you're calling him out early and making sure he doesn't act badly ... actually they're mostly similar depending on emphasis. They all work

response_to: I Was Challenged By My Viewer… And This Is The Outcome🥊😤
comment: the 'orh ___' is meant to be 'orh hor', 'orh hor' is used on somebody when he/she has done something wrong. like.... picture somebody wagging a finger and saying 'oh oh you're in trouble!'.

response_to: Japanese YouTuber Meets Dee Kosh | Famous Singapore YouTuber🇸🇬
comment: Regarding Dee Kosh's way of speaking.. I think singlish is a spectrum. But generally it is the essence of the Singaporean way of speaking english. If you go to the extreme end of full on Singlish, it can seem uncouth to some or even embarrass some singaporeans for others to know the most base way or speaking it. To be honest, singlish is not as well respected as the american/british/australian accents for various reasons.There are some singaporeans who try to speak with widely accepted english accents but some still frown upon those people for some reason. But I really respect how Dee Kosh embraces singlish unabashedly and OWNS it. Done like a boss

comment: あと、もう一つ近々旅行に行く人は知っておいて欲しい。シンガポールは実は一党独裁の国だと知ってますか？中国よりは自由で国際的にもオープンだし、シンガポール人の平均教養も高いので気がつきませんが、独裁国なのです。独裁国の特徴は良くも悪くも政府が決めれば物事が急激に動きます。もしもコロナウィルスに動きが出れば急に外出禁止令が出てもおかしくないのです。また日本の状況も良くない。クルーズ船での数が多いとはいえ日本は中国に次いで感染者数が多いのです。海外に住んでいる日本人にすれば、日本がいつ汚染国指定されて日本行きの飛行機が飛ばないとなるのが怖い。海外は歴史的に見ても日本より疫病に対しての恐怖感が強い。東日本大震災の時を見ても日本国内は結構落ち着いているのに海外では異様に恐れられた事を考えると、海外政府がいきなり日本をシャットアウトする可能性もあると思います。

response_to: A Day in My Life as a Traveling Busker | Taiwan🇹🇼
comment:
はじめまして。ジブリおじさんのフアンです。一日数回づつ拝見しています。昨年シンガポールへ行き大好きになり、今年6月に再渡航しました。一人旅です。その後SNSから知りました。私はあなたのお母様位の歳ですが、海外に興味があり、引き続き応援していきます。 
今 台風19号通過中です。凄く怖いです。被害なく通過するのを願う今夜です。

comment: Holland Village was named after Holland Road, which in turn was named after Hugh Holland in 1907; Holland, an architect and amateur actor, was an early resident of the area. comment:
The place where you had the Ya Kun coffee was where the wheel used to be. It was a decorative wheel.

The other "Holland" aspect of Holland village are the low rise HDB flats that are along the intersection of Commonthwealth Avenue and Holland Avenue. These low rise HDB are bulit using Dutch bricks. These are red bricks that were first developed by the Dutch.

comment:
初めての海外は学生の頃マンハッタン、NYでした。　
まだ、その頃は英語がよくわからなかった自分、レコード屋でJAPと言われ、コーヒースタンドでミルクを投げつけられたりし、言い返せなくてとても悔しかった。
仕事の関係で英語に触れる事が多くなって、なんとか日常会話は困らなくなってきた頃、出張でサンフランシスコへ行き、現地の人と話していると、お店の人がおまけしてくれたり、やはり言語は大事だなと思いました。

comment: おはようございます。アメリカ人です。残念ながらアメリカでは差別している人がまだ多いです。動画でおっしゃっていた通りアジア系の人に対してChing Chung Changを言う人が結構多いです。また、学校でアジア人がいれば、周りの学生たちはそのアジア系の学生が他の民族より数学が得意と思われます。しかし誰かにただNi Haoを言われたら、別に差別感があると思わないんです。アメリカ人のほとんどはアジア人を区別付けなくて、アメリカに住んでいるアジア人のほとんどは中国人なので、中国人だと勘違いされてただけです。動画は面白かったです。もし日本語を間違ったらすみません。

comment: 初めまして！私もアメリカの田舎で仕事しているので、白人優位主義の世界にドップリです。まぁ、差別のような言葉は言われたらジョークで交わすぐらいでないとダメですね。でもそれやってもずっと面白がって言われて、それもムカってきますが。仕事辞めようかと思ったことも一度ありました。でもジブリおじさんのようなことは言われたことないかも。。。ハハ。。。差別に対応できるようにならなくちゃいけないから、強くなりますよね。お話、面白かったです。

response_to: 日本人のぼくが海外で受けた差別の話をします
comment: 友人が言うには、中西部の田舎の州にいた時は人種は白人（肥満率が90％だとか）が多くてからかう・無視などのあからさまな差別は何回もあったそうです。ところが東海岸の某地区に越してからは、人種はバラエティーに富み、住んでいる人々の意識的・文化的・教育的レベルが高く、そのせいか態度を変えるというような差別もなく人々はフレンドリーだし非常に快適だと話していました。教養がない人の態度は、日本でも米国でも一緒のようですね。

response_to: Singapore Katong Adventure! Colorful Peranakan Houses🏠🇸🇬
comment: Ghib, I was sooo excited when I saw this title. I was like “Yes! He took my advice!” 😃🙏🏻 yup, there’s so many things that you missed. I was born and raised in that whole Katong/East Coast area. I was living at Siglap most of my life. Went to St.Patrick’s School 🤘 but you missed The Peranakan Museum. And also, the home of Encik Zubir Said, who is the composer of our national anthem. Majulah Singapura. You were so close to these 2 locations. The Eurasian Association is also nearby. But I still want to say thank you for heeding my advice of covering the Peranakan/ Eurasian culture. More to cover though. 😊👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍 ❤️🙏🏻

response_to: Singapore Katong Adventure! Colorful Peranakan Houses🏠🇸🇬
comment:
Unfortunately, Katong is indeed mostly food and the heritage building only. 

Do visit the Marine Parade area nearby and plan an east coast park cycling trip at the same time. Locals like to cycle in east coast park and cross the highway over to Marine Parade area for food, shopping and HDB life.

response_to: Singapore Katong Adventure! Colorful Peranakan Houses🏠🇸🇬
comment: Stayed at Katong area since I was born, so I think I can recommend some places. You HAVE to check out the food in that area (Eng’s wonton noodles, Katong shopping centre chicken rice, Donna Manis pastry and cakes, MIKI’s claypot rice at Katong Shopping Centre, Fried Hokkien noodles at Alibaba Coffeeshop, and the awesome bars along the whole stretch of road). It’s an area not just filled with heritage and culture, but also many famous food that’s been around that area for many years!

response_to: Singapore Katong Adventure! Colorful Peranakan Houses🏠🇸🇬
comment: 2:35 Katong has height restrictions on buildings because of the planes flying by :) The chicken rice/porridge at 8:43 is highly recommended, so is Mr and Mrs Morgan's prata at the corner coffeeshop with the cai fan. Some say that their prata is the best in SG. James can get his groceries at marine parade wet market, geylang serai wet market, parkway parade or i12 katong. Latter 2 will be much more convenient but expensive.

comment:
Katong Shopping Centre foodcourt (Basement) - Probably one of the best chicken rice places in SG. Prepare to wait at least 1/2 hour.

Serves 2 kinds of soup, which are refillable. Also refillable side salad (ah char) dish. Great boneless chicken. $6 per plate, but I'll recommend asking for half a chicken to share between 2 people.

comment: My nephew, born in Singapore went to Finland to grow up,  came back to serve NS last year, still in Artillery is considering staying here for further studies after his NS. Saw him as a timid boy nervous about going in for service, now a confident Artillery operator.  Fully acclimatised, well almost, Singaporean.  2 years in his early life to get this experience is priceless.  The period in their lives where they need to learn how to grow up to be independent and resposible. It's priceless!  Good on him,  Asao-san! Wish you a good experience in NS.

response_to: Does He Regret Being Half Singaporean/Japanese? His Take on National Service🎖️
comment: He picked up the Singlish accent so well

response_to: Does He Regret Being Half Singaporean/Japanese? His Take on National Service🎖️
comment: With  news of NS defaulters appearing frequently in the papers lately, especially of young people who hold citizenship but lived overseas for majority of their lives, its heartening to see lads returning to Singapore just to serve their NS. Actually hor, if you ask me, I served 2.5yrs of NS and 10yrs of ICT, NS is actually not that scary honestly, and since the lad here is half Singaporean, high chance he will not be posted to those demanding combat unit. Yes, it may take up 2 years of your life but if you factor in all the leaves, offs, public holidays etc, you are effectively serving <2yrs. And you get to meet a lot of interesting people who might turn out to be some of your best friends in life.

response_to: Does He Regret Being Half Singaporean/Japanese? His Take on National Service🎖️
comment:
私もシンガポールの母と日本の父のハーフで、幼稚園〜中学までをシンガポールに過ごした後、日本に戻り、10年ほど前にアサオさんと同じくNSを経験しました！（通信兵）
その当時でも、8人ほどの日本人ハーフや永住権保持者2世の方が兵役中だったと記憶しています。もう当たり前のように外国の血が入っている方々がシンガポールの兵役を経験していると思うと、さすがシンガポールといったところでしょうか… とにかく日本における就活でのネタには間違いなくなりますし、他の人がなかなかできない経験ですので、残り1年半も頑張ってくださいね！

response_to: 日本も真似すべき？シンガポールの会社の良い点3つ！日本と比較してどうなのか？【勤労3ヶ月記念】
comment: ジブおじが30半ば過ぎても今と同じことを（日本は良くない・海外は良い面いっぱい）言っているか興味あります。自分も20代をアメリカで過ごし、アメリカ大好き日本嫌い人間でした。それから時は流れ、もうあと数年で40。今は香港で年収2千万貰えているのでいわゆる成功した組に入ると思いますが、自由競争は年を取ると辛くもなります。日本にどうして年功序列や先輩後輩制度があるか考えると、やはりある程度年配に敬意を払うということだと思います。しかしこちらでは20代の優秀な若者とも張り合わないといけません。それでも勝ち抜いてきたのですから胸を張って良いと思いますが「なんだかなぁ」と想いにふけることも多々です。そうは言いつつも25を最後に日本では働いていませんし、日本の会社には戻れない・戻るつもりはないので自身で矛盾しているんですが…。結論は（日本の生産性の悪さなど問題点はいっぱい言いたいけど）日本も悪くはないよってことです。成長を見守ってます(^^)v

2，3訂正です。
※インフラ系が安いは少し表現が間違っています。
交通費と通信費は安いが、光熱費は高いです。(水道、電気については隣国MYより高い価格で輸入しているため、日本の2倍弱します。最近は、水道に関しては海水を真水に変える技術を導入し、3割程度それで賄っているので、値下げ傾向にあります。）

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment:
確かにそうですね。結局は国民が何を求めるのかによるのだと思います。経済や利便性を求め続ければ今のような日本になりますし、北欧のようなシンプルなライフスタイルを求めれば、経済大国の地位は失いますが、もっとゆったりとした生活になると思います。
スイスやニュージーランドは天然資源があまりない国でノルウェーのように石油も出ないですが、幸福度の高い国ランキングで毎回トップ１０に入ります。天然資源がある、ないも大きな要因だとは思いますが、どちらもシンプルな生活で、多くを求めてはいない気がします。仕事はあくまでも自分の生活の手段の一つでしかなく、中心にあるのは自分の生活なので、そこそこの生活水準でシンプルな生活に満足していることが幸福度の高い一因かなと思います。

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment: ノルウェー人なのですが、最近ビデオを拝見させていただいています。日本人の意見を見ると、見直しましたね。農業者は特別な生活をしてると思うんですよ。例の旦那さんの話をしてるときは、性格のイメージはすぐ出来ましたね。日本人は働きすぎとは言われたかもしれませんが、私からするとノルウェー人は連休を取りすぎてると思っています。夏には大体の連休は4週間を取る人が多く、もっと休みがほしいと言ってる人のことは理解できません。周りを気にしてるというのはいい考え方でもあると思いますよ。自己中心性のノルウェーはちょっと直した方がいいところはあります。ノルウェー人だからこそ言えるとは思いますが、ジブリおじさんがノルウェーの魅力的なところまでもを分かって下さって嬉しいです。

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment: ノルウェーが何が好きかって？そりゃあ自然の美しさですよ。山も湖も森も畑でさえ美しく見える。とても良い動画でしたね。あんなに綺麗な場所は見た事がありません。日本の自然とは全く雰囲気が違いますね。来年はシンガポールでの生活が始まるけど今回の様に半年くらい経ったら教えて下さいね。本当に一年間有難うございました、お疲れ様でした。

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment: よくノルウェーを見習えとか言われるけど　資源国と　全く資源のない日本を比べること自体が間違い　資源国は寝ていても資源がでて　国民が潤う　当然資源の出ている間は　幸福でうらやましがられるが　結局　産業や技術などが育たないので　資源が枯渇すると最悪になる　資源国の呪いと言われる　　日本は資源がないので知恵をお金に変えていくしかない　当然勤勉・働き者になるし産業・技術が発展する　また頭の中から出てくるお金なので枯渇することがない　結局は苦しいが　資源のない国日本が一番良いと思う　　ナウル共和国という国を調べてみるとよくわかる　資源のあるうちは贅沢な暮らしをし　税金もなく　国民みんなが働く必要がなく豊かだったが　資源がなくなった現在　最貧国となって悲惨な状況である　面白いもので資源国は裕福な間はそれがずっと続くと信じている　そして資源がなくなった時のための技術革新・知識の向上などを絶対にしない　ロシア・サウジアラビア・ノルウェー・等々　それらの国のたどる道はみな同じ　アリとキリギリス　でキリギリスは　「アリさんどうしてそんなにあくせく働くの　こんなに幸せなのに　もっと人生を楽しめばいいじゃないか」　　資源の出る高福祉国家が日本人をみていう言葉と同じに聞こえる

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment: 世界に出て色々な経験を積むのは良いことだと思います。同じ国の中でも、場所やコミュニティーによって、ぜんぜん違うものだと思います。日本は同調圧力が高いので、そういう違いは起きにくいのかもしれないですが…。今は私はアメリカで働いていますが、職場の人はくらいうちから会社に来て、昼休みも最低限しか休まず、早く帰ります。効率よく働いているのだと思います。なお、以前はインドに５年いましたが、インドは非常に奥深いところで、インドに行く前よりも、インドを離れる時のほうが、自分がインドを理解していないという実感がありました。ある謎を解くと、その後ろにあるたくさんの謎が出てくるという感じです。台湾の動画も拝見させていただきましたが、高雄の方に行くと、新しい発見があると思います。

response_to: 北欧ノルウェーにプチ移住した感想｜3ヶ月の住み込みボランティア体験（WWOOF）
comment: この様なルポルタージュのヴィデオを拝見したのは初めてですが、大変興味深い、そしてご本人の感想が率直に受け取れ、良い新たな感想、ノルウエイ社会の農業関係の一端を知ることができました。一つ作者に申したいのは、ノルウェイは、大変経済的に恵まれている国です。　北海の石油がこの国の経済を潤しています。　これが、職場での余裕などの源泉で、同じスカンジナヴィア諸国ではかなり異なった経験をされるでしょう。　わたしは五十年以上前に日本から米国に移り、’４０何カ国か、主として貿易の仕事で頻繁に訪問、各地の人間の生き方、考え方を知るべく努力したつもりです。　初めての仕事場での同僚、ドイツ、フランス、イタリー？などのやりっぱなしの話とか、同じような欧州人のミックスの次の職場では異なった印象など、非常におもしろい経験ですが、欧米に限らず、世界どこでも、日本人の物の考え、育ち方、習慣など、集団生活を基本としての伝統からくるものと、集団生活をするけれども基本はしっかりと骨身にしみている、個人主義（自分第一）との違いを、どちらがいい悪いではなく、理解していかねばならない、ということです。　ノルウェイには数回ゆき、現在でも政府関係の仕事をする女性と文通をしていますが、この人は５０代ですが、過去十年に、中国の孤児、みなしご、捨て子を３人、一人一人　三年ほど間をおいて、中国にゆき、養子にして、自ら家を建て、一流の教育とそれを支える環境を作り、世界の上流社会でも自らの子供に与えられないような、色々な芸術、音楽、スポーツ、（教養をつけさせ）などを習わせ、（勿論家庭の仕事の手伝いも）政府の仕事の傍に子供達を育てています。　このような人物、”慈善”を個人でしている、できる、これも、ノルウエイで今は廃れてきたが伝統的な宗教の影響に則り、人道主義の実行者が大勢いるでしょうが、これらをできるのは、国家経済の豊かさが影響しています。別に日本の良さ、優れた伝統をあれこれ言うわけではありませんが、海外の色々な社会での異なった見解、文化を見極めて、このようなヴィデオで一般の人々（我々現在の日本人）に教えてください。

response_to: 🇲🇾Is JB Really Dangerous? Crossed the Border to Malaysia
comment: 私の勝手な憶測ですが、ガクト氏やちか友さんのような高額所得者は租税回避目的でマレーシアを拠点にしてると思ってます。所得税ゼロのラブアン島に会社を設立することでマレーシア本土の居住ビザが得られるうえ、うまくやれば驚きの所得税ゼロが可能です。もちろんシンガポールもタックスヘイブン国ですがシンガポール政府は先進諸国と歩調を合わせて租税回避に厳しい対応を取ることで知られています。一方、ちか友さんの場合は贈与税・相続税のないオーストラリアと、ラブアン島があるマレーシアというタックスヘイブン地域を移動しているので、うまくやっているのではと思っています。ガクト氏はさらに不動産会社を設立してマレーシアが新規開発してる地域の土地に投資をしているという噂ですので、タックスヘイブンによって節税して得た利益を今後値上がりが期待されるマレーシアの不動産に投資して大儲けを目論んでいると私個人は考えています。またマレーシアの銀行預金の金利が年3%と高いことも考えられます。いずれにせよ高所得者の節税および投資が主な居住目的だと考えます。

response_to: Here's How My Property Viewing Went…💰🇸🇬 Foreigner Buying a Resale HDB in Singapore
comment: For whichever area or flat you were viewing, you should also return to the area during the night to see how is the environment at night.  You don't have to disturb the home owner, it's just to make sure that even at night you are comfortable with it.  No harm doing it a few time too, (day and night) cos its going to be a place you will stay for along while. This is just a little advice.

response_to: Here's How My Property Viewing Went…💰🇸🇬 Foreigner Buying a Resale HDB in Singapore
comment: A quick tip will be in Singapore, never ever view those empty plots of land as a "view" because in a few years' time those land will be repurposed for something. That's Singapore right there, always developing. There are a lot of places in Singapore for you to view if you want cheap and potential future development you have Choa Chu Kang and Jurong East. If you want something near the seaside you'll have Woodlands to Yishun and Marine Parade or basically anything along the ECP. Take your time, because it will most likely be somewhere where you'll be staying for a long time.

response_to: Here's How My Property Viewing Went…💰🇸🇬 Foreigner Buying a Resale HDB in Singapore
comment: There is probably not much point in asking the owner if they have bad neighbours, cause even if there are, they will probably say no. Just try to look out for signs yourself: do your neighbours keep their corridor area clean, do they have a lot of plants (potential dengue source), does it seem like they block up the corridor with their stuff and eat into your space, are there weird smells and noises etc.

response_to: Here's How My Property Viewing Went…💰🇸🇬 Foreigner Buying a Resale HDB in Singapore
comment: If u are considering a resale flat, other than the day & night environment, views, one important factor to look out for is to observe the ceiling and walls around windows for any sign of water seepages / leakages. The upper unit may have damaged the waterproofing when doing renovations to their toilets & kitchen. Also some owners replaced their windows & also there may be water seepages around the windows as the building aged. Hope u find your ideal home. Cheers.

⑨人に求めすぎないようになった
これは海外の労働環境と比較する際に重要な点だと思う。
ジブおじさんも触れてるけど、日本では「過剰サービス」のせいで、客には優しいが、労働者には厳しい世界だと思う。これが残業に繋がることもしばしばあると思うので、もっとバランスすると良いかと思う。

response_to: 海外で働いて変わったこと、変わらなかったこと
comment:
中国の会社に居た時に感じたのは
中核メンバーの数人の社員は日本人の何倍も働き、殆ど自分のデスクにおらず、基本的に背広を着、高給を取って良い生活をし、
そうで無いメンバーはそこそこ働き、そこそこの給料を貰い、普段着で会社に来て、定時に帰っていく。

comment: I’m not gonna lie, I watch more of your videos than any other Singaporean Youtuber’s videos. comment: Agreed that Singaporeans can sometimes be too honest. response_to: Another 3 Things You Should NOT Do To Japanese
comment: I have to say foreigners who use another country's language to greet Japanese would just be too disrespectful... in fact, it's not just dissing Japanese, but imo it's Japanese and Chinese (whether people or the culture).  Then again, there are those who see Asia / Southeast Asia / as 'one country' and cannot tell apart any race  other than their own.  We still have a long way to go to become a global village indeed, but THANK YOU for your efforts to bring light to some acts of ignorance.

Cool video! I have always likened the idea of 本音 (hon'ne) and 建前 (tatemae) to the idea of 面子 (mian zi), a chinese term about "saving face" or keeping up with social appearances.

I am not aware on how prevalent it is in Singapore but saving face seems to be pretty widespread in Asian countries in general.

response_to: What the Japanese Need To Learn From Singaporeans | Happy New Year! [cc]
comment: As a Singaporean, all I can say when Singaporeans compliment you (or anyone), we mean it and that means you deserve the compliment. However, we can also be honestly truthful if you suck, and if we odn't like it, we tell you we don't like it. Westerners on the other hand, from my own experience, sometimes their compliments come across as fake and I know it (when I myself feel it's really bad). Compliments given in that way lack sincerity and people will start not to take your compliments (or criticisms) seriously because it just seems so flippant.

comment: I love how you cover all the spots in Singapore Ghib-Ojisan! For a suggestion on where to go next in Singapore, I suggest you go to some of our natural attractions! response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: My eldest brother died as a baby in the Japanese Occupation of Singapore. My parents were running away from the blitz when a Japanese plane dropped a bomb close by. My mother instinctively put her hands to her ears and dropped my brother who was barely 3 months old. He fell down the stairs and died. That night, my father buried his little lifeless body, wrapped in a straw mat, at the hill behind the flats at Kreta Ayer Road, China town. They were too shocked to even grieve.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: Dear Ghibli Ojisan, my late Peranakan father had forgiven the Japanese soldiers a long time ago. He said it was war. 🌿 Please allow me to share with you how my grandpa had died during WW2.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: Hey you are a good person to even talk about this. You have my respect friend.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment:
Brave of you to touch on this sensitive topic. 

Sadly, many of my Japanese friends denied that the Imperial Army killed many innocent people in SG and the Sook Ching operation. Reason: they were not covered in the Japanese History text books in school.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: My opinion has always been to not blame children for the sins of their parents.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: This is a really good video. We, Japanese people, tend to forget what the Japanese army did in South East Asia during the war because the relationships with countries in the region are currently good. However, I think we have to know the dark side of history to keep good relationships.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment:
Just to give some perspective on how fast times change:
1. My grandma lived through WWII and the Japanese Occupation. She hated the mention of anything Japanese although she tolerated the gradual globalisation of Japanese culture.
2. My aunt (1 gen after grandma) married a Japanese man, and moved over to Japan when her oldest son was about 11 or 12. We visit them in Japan occasionally and they have fully integrated back into Japanese society. I have a Japanese niece who is just a few years old now :)

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: 1年前から比べて確実にシンガポールの本当の姿をレポートしてくれるようになって　とても良くなってるし　日本が過去にこの美しい南国の島で起こしてしまった間違いをしっかり勉強して伝える事　それはとても大切な事　そして　この国にこうして住まわせて貰ってる事仕事させて貰ってる事に心から感謝する姿勢も大切です。　イーシュンのレポートやtoday の記事で見て　久しぶりに　見に来たけれど　素晴らしい成長に　同じ日本人として誇りに思った。　戦争の事はチャンギの戦争歴史館や今国立美術館でやってるシンガポール歴史展などを観てもらうともっと深く理解出来ると思う。　　これからがもっと楽しみ。　日本人で固まるクセのある多くの日本人と違ってどんどんシンガポールのローカルの中に入って行って、新しいシンガポールの日本人像を作っていって下さい。　楽しみにしてる。　どこかで会える日を楽しみしてます

comment: paecpc I don’t think u can say that for those (rest of the Singaporeans) that have lost their immediate loved ones because of Japanese soldiers actions. Of course as year goes by, with lesser of the victims & direct victims of ww2  around, the pain felt by them will be gone with their passing.  For the younger generations, it’s just liked reading history. Other places liked Korean where there’s more comfort ladies, the pain they suffered during war have permanent ‘scars’ on their lives. They never seem to walk out of the pain they suffered.... even thought so many years have passed. It’s really sad.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: 大学卒業後、シンガポールに仕事で13年いました。お世話になったファミリーのおばあちゃんが戦時中の子供のころのお話をしてくれました。日本軍が来て、家族全員どこかに移動させられているとき、怖くて泣きそうだったのを唇を食いしばってこらえていたのを側にいた日本兵が見て、「よしよし泣くなよ」というような形で頷いてそばを通って行ったのを憶えているそうです。もうお亡くなりになりましたが、戦争のことで僕が一度も責められたことはありませんでした。

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: 毎年2月15日には追悼式が行われますね。2017年には現地日本人学校の児童生徒全員で折った鶴を生徒代表2名が持参して追悼しました。ナショナルミュージアム、旧フォード工場（オールドフォードファクトリー）にも昭南時代の展示品が見られます。現地日本人学校の児童生徒が社会科学習として訪問して過去の歴史を学んでいます。もし機会があったら訪れてみてください。

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: I remember when my grandmother used to tell me about her past experiences living through the Japanese occupation(blood on bayonet rifles, as she would say it)(eating tree roots/barks and water with just a few grains of rice just to survive), mostly about my grandfather who tried to help others as best as he can regardless of how poor of a condition he was in. That he would beg and plea for others who were suspects to be against the occupation and his head would be buried beneath the mud under the soldier's boots, he was mostly lucky she said but his luck ran out when he was drag away one evening never to return again(she teared while struggling to say this part). Because of that she grabbed what she can and escaped to the nearby woods with her children fearing what's about to come.

Thank you Ojisan for making the video. As a Japanese descendant, you’re willing to face the war sin of your forefathers.  You have my respect.

Mum told me that her father went through Sook Ching. He was asked, “do you know Chiang Kai-shek?” My grandpa said that he didn't know who he was and he did not receive education. response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment:
I'd like to share some things about my family as well.

My grandfather was born during the Japanese occupation and the family had to hide from the soldiers for several days. His family was lucky that they did not get 'selected', and the worst is only that we never really knew when his actual birthday was. At that point of time too, our families had to force marriages between their daughters and other men so that the Japanese will not take them away, and my grandmother's older sisters were married off this way.

response_to: What did Japan do to Singapore? | Civilian War Memorial - Sook Ching🇸🇬
comment: Thank you Ghibli Ojisan for making this video so that I can share this with my Japanese friends. I am a Singaporean in my 30s and worked in Japan as an ALT for 2 years. I love both Singapore and Japan. I have not been through the war and have no ill feelings towards the Japanese, but every time I hear "Kimigayo" I feel uncomfortable and refuse to look at the flag, can't quite explain why. Another interesting tidbit I wanted to share is that my parents' generation use the term "3 years 8 months" to mean "a long long time" (for example, if I'm late, my mum will say "I've waited 3 years 8 months for you!") 3 years 8 months is the length of time Japan occupied Singapore, and that number is etched in our language.

comment:
こどもの頃、20歳になったら大人になると思っていました。
でも20歳の誕生日の朝、そこにいたのは昨日と同じ自分でした。
年齢が変わっただけ、登録者が増えただけでは、本質は変わらないのでしょう。
ただ、それをきっかけとして、無自覚な程のとても小さな覚悟とかぼんやりとした理想が心の中に芽生えているのかもしれません。

comment:
恭ちゃんは、数字はまやかしだと語っていました。結局、自分が本当にやりたい事をしていれば、それを面白いと思ってくれる人が見てくれるはずなので、数字がどうこうよりも、自分が楽しいと思える事を優先した方が良いと思います。
数字がどうこうとか考えると、どこぞの炎上ユーチューバーみたいに非道徳的な事になってしまうので注意が必要です。

comment:
ほんとに、ジブリおじさんの動画大好きです！！
特に、ジブリの舞台になった所でそのテーマソングを弾くなんて、もう最っ高です。千と千尋の神隠しの｢いつも何度でも｣は死にかけました。いまでも、時々見てます！
陰ながら応援しています！

response_to: 半年で登録者500→6万人まで伸びて感じたことを話します
comment: ジブおじさんには沢山の魅力があるかと思いますが、一番凄いのは有言実行な事だと思います。世界一周旅行、ギターでジブリの聖地を巡る、海外就職、ビワイチなど、全てやり遂げている事が凄いです。誰しも考える事はできるけど、行動に移せる人はそのうち一握りで限られてくると思いますので。

comment:
いくつかのチャンネル登録をしていますが、情報をくれる動画とかは、暇なときに後から見ようって思うんですが、ジブおじさんのは、今見ようって思うんですよね。

response_to: 半年で登録者500→6万人まで伸びて感じたことを話します
comment: いつに無く崖っぷちに立ってる様な気分を出してるね。行き詰ってる感出てるよ。人は生きて行く上で目標が無いと目的を失いがちになるから持ってないとね。でも その目的は途中で変わっても良いし、増やしても良い。登録者数が増えてもグットボタンや再生、コメが無ければ増えた感が伝わらないのは分かるよ。自分は絶対毎回コメ出すし、と言うより出したい。結構長いコメだから悪いなぁ〜って思いながら出してるよ、なんかジブさんと話が出来る唯一の手段だからね。見るだけの一方通行で無いから楽しくなる、どうしょうもない動画で沢山のコメとかあるけど内容の濃いジブさんの動画が皆んな安心して見ているんじゃないかな？という事で、今日は髪の毛ふわふわの生地サラサラで纏ってるね😊襟付きの服も初めて見ました。面白い顔をすると何度も見てしまうよ。え？今日はしてない？はい！失礼しましたぁ〜。

comment: 「海外にいると日本の良さが分かる」というのはその通りだと思います。悪さもわかりますが。４０歳を過ぎてから、（想像していなかった）いきなりの海外転勤命令でインドに行きました。なれると仕事は日本より楽しくやり甲斐がありました。もっと長くいたかったのですが５年で一旦帰国。その後はアメリカにいますが、色々な意味で日本より生活環境は良いと思います。海外なれしてしまうと日本での会社勤めは辛いです。旅行だけで考えると、時間がたつにつれて刺激は無くなりますが、職場環境で考えると日本が最高だとは言えないです。次にいけるとしたらシンガポールで働いてみたいです。休日が少なく会社も割と厳しいと聞いていますが、シンガポールを起点に旅行に行くには良い場所ですよね。

comment: 海外に住むと日本の良さを感じることが多いですね。長く住むとなると、人生設計（年金、医療、教育費）に影響与えるから、日本では考えられなかった不安も増えますね。シンガポールに住んでた時は、外国人でも”シンガポールのための教育拠出金”が税金でかかっていたので、我が子の子供の教育を受けさせるならいいですけど、いづれ日本に帰るなら、なんか寄付をしている感覚で、なんだかなーという感じでした。

Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: The story goes that the lady is poor and the family is starving and she only have enough  breast milk to feed one person. However she chose to feed her mum over her own baby. That scene is to depict filal piety.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: Drinking Kickapoo while visiting Haw Par Villa. Talk about retro.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: The souvenir shop lady was so polite and pleasant. Almost a waste for her to be working at a semi-deserted park.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: Haw Par Villa has to be one of the few true fascinating actual historic heritage locations left in SG, that’s a great tourist spot that’s not a modern spot purposely made for tourists. It has a great back story of how the Haw older brother bought his younger brother a actual Villa, which is no longer there, it’s now an empty spot that kinda looks like a very tiny amphitheater. And then also build all the dioramas to uphold Chinese culture as a way of giving back to the public. There was another similar place in Hong Kong which I’m not sure if it’s still there.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: Living in Singapore my whole life, that was the friendliest shop lady i have ever seen

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: "I really hope I don't get demonetized for this." I LOL-ed. Priorities damn straight, Ghib! 😂

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: I know the woman in the snail shell story! She's 田螺姑娘. A man saved this snail and brought it home to rear it. She turns into a lady to do his housework while he goes to work. Eventually they got married :)

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: 10:55 I think this is referring to a Chinese idiom called " 鸡同鸭讲", which literally translates to "chicken with duck speaking", describing a situation of miscommunication. Thus you see the guy with duck head having a bit of a fight with the lady with chicken head.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: "oh what happened here" proceed to show a woman breastfeeding "too chaotic" 😂

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: The builders of this place, Aw Boon Haw and Aw Boon Par, were ethnically Chinese but born and raised in Burma (now called Myanmar) back when both Singapore and Burma were under British colonial rule. You can find similar gardens in Hong Kong and China as well, along with traces of their family's influence in business, philanthropy and charity in other places like Myanmar. You can still find their descendants today spread all over the world but they've mostly lost all of their connections to the Haw Par businesses and their fortune along with it. The Aw family and the Haw Par businesses are quite a lot to read about on their own.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: I can feel Ghib is getting more and more localized with each passing day (Check out his Singlish!).  This place is not only giving moral lesson to the kids, but it also remind us that no matter what's the situation, avoid doing bad things to others. Instead, do more good deeds and it will be rewarded accordingly when the time comes. TLDR: Teaches you about "Karma"

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: When I was young, my parents bought me to the park with my cousins, then it was free. I never really like this place since there wasn't anything interesting about it other than walkways to climb. Towards the 90s the park charged exorbitant fee, the highlight was the boat ride into ten levels of hell. For many years I had never attempted to come here again. Your video has spurred me to find out about the story features of  each figurine and statue. There is so much to learn about Chinese culture through these stories and it has always been right there.. for me to find.

response_to: Singapore's Most Bizarre Tourist Attraction! 🇸🇬Haw Par Villa
comment: This was one of my favourite places to go when I was a kid. It used to be so boisterous and crowded. It had water rides and food stalls... So fun... I loved reading all the stories in the park. The statues never really frightened me somehow...although they left a very deep impression on me.

comment: Foreigners like to congregate to do their shopping, eating or banking services. Filipinos go to Lucky Plaza, Thai at Golden Mile Complex at Beach Road, Myanmar nationals go to Peninsula Plaza, Indonesians go to City Plaza, Chinese nationals go to Geylang or Chinatown, Indians go Little India and Japanese used to go Liang Court and probably Great World now.

comment: Love this feature!! I miss Filipino food. Good choice on the bicol express. It's my favourite too. Barrio Fiesta literally means "town feast." Both words are Spanish from the colonial times. response_to: シンガポール人の働き方を見て思うこと【日本人と比較】
comment:
日本が島でなく東南アジア辺りと陸続きだったらなぁと思うことが時々あります。
嫌になったら気軽に車に荷物積んで隣国に引っ越し&移住ができるので。

日本は島国ゆえに国防面は有利なのですが、その海に囲まれた閉鎖された空間のため良くも悪くも皆、一連托生。悪いときは地獄まで道連れを喰らう。言語や文化なども特殊であり、逃げ場がない。

comment:
芸人の中田敦彦がが自分のチャンネルの授業で「シンガポールは明るい北朝鮮」っていたのは多分一番ひろげた原因と思います。あの方の話術、修辞学は認めますか、政治経済は基本池上彰しか情報源がないので、事実の確認欠けている。
ぎぶさんおしゃる通り「シンガポールは明るい北朝鮮」は言い方として面白いかもしれないか、それを過信して満足すると、シンガポール制度の歴史的背景と合理性を全殺ししてしまい、客観的にシンガポールを認識することができない。

response_to: Is Singapore Really 'Bright' North Korea?
comment: Interesting topic; I never knew we are perceived as Bright N.Korea by Japanese. Actually, I think living in Japan may be more restrictive due to the culture. A Japanese friend who lives in Singapore told me that hierarchy is very important to Japanese. She cited one example. Japanese mums waiting with their children for the school bus at the side of the road in the mornings have to stand according to their 'hierarchy', i.e if the wife of the husband with the most senior position in the company gets to stand first in the queue, followed by the next senior person and so on. Is that true Jippon Lang?

response_to: Is Singapore Really 'Bright' North Korea?
comment: I'm a Singaporean and I honestly never heard about the term "bright North Korea" term until I've watched this video.  However, I do understand how bizarre it is for example, people from countries that can chew gum, find it ridiculous that bubble and chewing gum it's banned in Singapore.  But if they research deeper, it was because people used to vandalize by sticking gum on lift buttons, etc.  For other's consideration and hygiene reasons, chewing gum is banned. the rules are meant for citizens to follow as a means for consideration because we have people coming from different parts of the world with different cultures and considerations to others. I hope to watch more of such interesting videos! Good work!!

comment: シンガポールというと罰金刑が厳しいだの言論が統制されているだの国の制度面に注意が向きがちですが、実際の社会生活に於いては日本と比べてもかなりストレスが少なく自由度、満足度も高い国ではないでしょうか。翻って日本を見てみると、今回のコロナ騒ぎの際にも明るみに出てきたように、国の法整備が甘くても無言の圧力によって民間側が感染拡大の防止に努めるといったことがなされてきていますが、個人としての自由が不明瞭な形で制限されているのが日本だと思います。あと政府や公官庁レベルでの汚職の問題ですが、この点については実のところ日本はシンガポールに遥か及ばないのではないかと思うのは自分だけではないと思います。自分たちの代表が不正にばかり手を染めていると、政府のみならず社会生活全般に於いても不満が募ってきますよね。。

response_to: Accidentally Visiting the Haunted Road in Singapore🇸🇬Tampines Vlog
comment: Visit Changi Village. You will find a lot of creepy stories about that area on the internet, especially where the old Changi hospital was. But do not miss the hawker centre. If you have time, you can even take a boat to Pulau Ubin at the jetty. Oh, the place where you said you had goosebumps while walking on the street. It used to be a village until early 1980. I used to live at the kampong there in the 70's.

comment: That haunted stretch starts from the turn in off Tampines Ave 10, where many many temples sit side-by-side, and goes along the back of Paya Lebar Airbase till you seen the KPE expressway. You really don't want to wait for the bus at those bus stops at night, or even drive past there if you can help it...

response_to: 実は簡単？海外移住・就職の6つのステップ｜シンガポール在住者が解説
comment:
海外の会社に応募する際、面接の際に最も大事なのは「はったり」です。
海外の企業では面接時のはったりは当たり前です。
というか日本人が「謙遜しすぎる」、「自己評価が低すぎる」のだとおもいます。
すごいやつ（同期入社外人）などになると、上司に「お前、採用面接でできるって言っただろ！」といわれると、その外人「できるとは言ったが、やるとは言っていない」などと平気で言い訳します。

comment: There is a reason for the loudness and chaotic scene on the eve of Chinese Lunar New Year. It is believed that with the setting off of firecrackers and having ornaments in red, it will scare off the monster (called Nian). That was the legend. Use noise and colour to scare off the mystical creature which had been terrorizing the rural villages for years.

response_to: Japanese Reacting to Chinese New Year in Singapore🇸🇬
comment: Hahaha! Thanks Ghib, for sharing this vlog! This really suits the festivities now! 😄😄  About the Yu Sheng, it is indeed from Singapore- a dish invented by 4 Cantonese chefs who wanted to create something that uses simple everyday ingredients in a novel way that celebrates the CNY. Now about the phrases, you’d have to maybe be a Cantonese to enjoy the deeper meanings; besides the auspicious phrases used to describe each ingredient- sometimes with a play of words and as a wish to the business man customers dining at the restaurant (after which the diners will typically tip the waitress) it was served with raw fish slices- the phrase which was 年年有餘 (Having abundance every year) while placing the fish over the ingredients (as 年年有魚)- “Having “Fish” every year”. But the call out was not “Huat” before; it’s “Loh-ah” (捞啊!) which means (getting into business/doing well in business/working hard for business- generally speaking) but it also means “to Mix” in Cantonese; the act of mixing up the ingredients to its final for-consumption stage. The “Huat-ah!” came about because we are culturally diverse and being a majority of Hokkien dialect in Singapore evolves into “Huat-ah!” In Cantonese families, we still use “Loh-ah!” for example. The spillage is not an intended practice as you may be able to imagine how the prim and proper business man in the 60’s would’ve behaved in such a dinner setting. But the consumption of this auspicious dish quickly spread to many many families, in restaurants, in coffee shops and of course the homes. And when this is done in families with little ones or among a group of rowdy friends, squeezed for space to get in on the auspicious action of “Loh-ing” for good luck and prosperity, this do get out of hand- no pun intended. Whilst this practice originated as Cantonese’s, very soon Teochew have their very own style of ingredients used and the type of fish used. But since the ban of raw fish a few years ago, its been down to abalone strips or salmon...which in my opinion, is less tasty now. This practice of course was practiced in Malaysia very quickly because of the huge base of Cantonese there. But surprisingly, the largest base of Cantonese in HK or Guangzhou has only very recently done this.

comment: Well they're definitely not the correct group to advise for Yu Sheng. Yes, Yu Sheng is originated from Singapore, by the 4 master chefs, known as 'Four Heavenly King'. Each sauces and ingredients added in are accompanied by a significant phrases. In modern time, usually the veggies have been plated , leaving the plum sauce, pepper and cinnamon, raw fish and oil for the server to add in. Raw fish can also be substituted with abalones or fried fish skin, depending on individual preferences.

response_to: Possibly The Most Beautiful Town in Singapore | PUNGGOL🇸🇬
comment: Your YouTube clips are great! I go through Singapore fairly regularly now, spending three or so nights on my way back to Sydney from Tokyo. I have often seen Punggol as I think a terminating station in the MRT, but never been there. It might indeed be worth an afternoon, just to see the beach, walk or ride through the riverside, and check out the amazing architecture. Singapore is great for an architecture buff like me, as I enjoy taking lots of photos of great architecture and cityscapes, editing them on photoshop for artistic effect etc. Just a hobby. I haven’t gone through all your clips yet, but have you checked out Tiong Bahru? It is possibly my favourite part of Singapore. Streamline Moderne housing estate. Also, have you walked around Alexandra Park where a whole lot of Black and White houses are located. Very leafy,  dry green, very quiet, and beautiful architecture. I wanted to to travel in July this year, to Tokyo and Singapore, but I might have to put that on hold until the Covid-19 is no more. Keep up the great work!

response_to: 🇸🇬Japanese Visiting Singapore's Most Dangerous Area | Yishun Vlog
comment: I brought a friend from Tokyo to Yishun 2 months ago as she wanted a 地元 experience and it was my hometown area. She didn't notice anything amiss 😏 I brought her to Chong Pang Market and had Chong Pang Nasi Lemak near the air base located at Sembawang Road. Oh I saw a friend at 7:20, there was a funeral wake going on which I attended yesterday's evening. In fact, I recognised most of the places you went as I live around the area. The reason as to why there are plenty of security cameras in the mrt stations was probably due to the fact that Yishun MRT station was a targeted terrorist bomb attack which was foiled in 2001.

comment: Hey, since this house looks like it's in the Newton area, you should walk down past the MRT station to Balmoral Plaza and check out this restaurant called "Waffletown". You might also wanna see Newton Hawker center which is nearby the MRT. I live near the area so if you'd ever like a tour I'd be glad to show you around.

response_to: I Collabed With a Local YouTube Channel! 👴🏻Our Grandfather Story
comment:
海外と日本を比べると、どこにでも綺麗なトイレが無料で入れて、ゴミ箱も探せばある、
お店がたくさん、アニメ・漫画が良い、みんなお洒落、歴史がある、食べ物が世界トップレベルに美味いと思う
でも、人が多すぎる、電柱多すぎて景観が悪い、英語が苦手、陰湿な性格、歩いてると避けない所かぶつかりに来る

response_to: 【本当は知りたくない】水の都ベネチアの残念な現実5選

良い点もあれば悪い点もある、これはベネチアに限らずどこの国もある事ですよね笑

response_to: 【本当は知りたくない】水の都ベネチアの残念な現実5選
comment: ションベン臭いのはビール飲んだ後の立ちションベンだと思う。グラフィティはもちろん、欧州ならどこでもひどい。でもこれ知らない日本人割りと多いかもしれないと思って見た。パリなんかも案外ひどい。あと、これ結構大事だと思うのだけど、スウェット生地みたいなのでうろうろしてると低く見られてまともに取り合ってくれない（ダウンにジーンズ、ニット帽もダメなことがある）場合が意外と多い。かと言ってあまり高級な服だと物取りに狙われることも。

response_to: 【本当は知りたくない】水の都ベネチアの残念な現実5選
comment:
いつも　色々な動画を楽しく拝見させて頂いています。☺️
8月にヴェネチアに行った時に
蚊がいる事を予想して　ホテルにチェックインしたら　部屋に殺虫剤を撒いて観光に行き　部屋に戻った時には　隠れていた蚊も退治されていて　快適でした。😁

comment: Hi Ghibli. I only discovered your channel about 3 weeks ago & have been an ardent follower since. You've truly hit us in the right spot with your videos on food centres. Changi boardwalk is one of our favourite walking area, but we never really took notice of LIB until you video. Keep up the good work & continue being honest with your opinions, be it good or bad. Hope to catch you on one of adventures sometime. In the meantime stay safe.

response_to: How is it Really Like Living in Japan?🇯🇵Singaporeans Living Abroad
comment: Japan creates technology like it has super cool high tech toilets, vending machines and robots but also reluctant to change and move forward in certain areas. Everything is still done on paper, schools still using chalk and blackboard for teaching, slow adoption in e-learning/ contactless payment/mobile banking, bank book and seal are still very essential, etc. All these lead to a difficulty in learning and working from home.

response_to: How is it Really Like Living in Japan?🇯🇵Singaporeans Living Abroad
comment: interesting episode, I love it! In my view, the 'moral standard' that Lydia mentioned is more apparent in countries with homogenous society such as Japan. You 're probably not going to see that in Singapore; in fact strict laws are implemented (and enforced) in Singapore to ensure that people follow certain 'standard' or behave in certain way. I think it is ingrained in people  that if you don't see the '$' sign you probably think you can do whatever you want as it means you won't be fined lol.  this '$' sign probably works in older Singaporean generation as many do not read ( due to lack of schooling  opportunities) but know what $ sign means.  I hope that current and future generations do not rely on the 'fine' culture but behave out of morality tho..

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: The area near the MRT has been completely renovated, so they look very new to you! If you want the old neighbourhood feel, you did go to one at the place you ate food at! You did walk past some of the oldest HDB blocks, such as the 4 storey blocks and the maisonettes which are the double-storey HDB flats you showed in the video. They are running out of their 99-year lease soon. You can tell the difference between the old and new blocks very easily! There are more 'ulu' quieter areas, but I suggest going to the area around Tampines West Community Centre for some old neighbourhood feel. Good food and has a wet market in the early morning. That's the old neighbourhood feel you want to experience; our grandparents shop for food at the wet market. The area around Tampines East CC is also another place you can explore too!

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: Hi hi, if u want to visit this round market at tampines, the busy time is in the morning. This timing is when u can get the best popular food. By noon, most stalls be closed. Go between 7am to 10am. But be prepared that it will be packed.

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: Welcome to the east!!! By the way, the market that you had visited is quite famous in the east. It is round in shape and have lots of good food. However, most of the hawker stores opens only from early morning until early afternoon. And if you had visited the market during chinese new year, most of the stores will be closed as well. Come back after chinese new year to try some of the food here. Since you are exploring east, you can consider visiting Fengshan Food Centre, 85 Bedok North Street 4 at night. Lots of good food at night!

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: Every Friday/Sunday, if you head to Pasir Ris Bus interchange on the right end, you will see many Army boys from Basic Military Training there. Friday is the day they come out from the training island and Sunday is the day they return back to the Island for training. The buses will be at Pasir Bus interchange. Usually every hour from the afternoon till night.

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: i have stayed in Tampines for 38 years since i was 6 years old when there was no bus interchange and the trees you see along the roads are just planted. Compared to many older neighbourhood, Tampines is quite young. in fact, it was once called Tampines new town. Because of the close proximity to Changi Airport, Tampines was sort of like a small business hub and a popular choice for expats who need to travel frequently and professionals who need to work at the airport. That is some of the reasons why it was so well developed and have so many malls compared to many neighbourhoods in the east.

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬

response_to: The Most Livable Area in Singapore is Full of Fruits! Tampines🇸🇬
comment: Hey Ghib! Try going to west side of Singapore, Jurong East and Jurong West ! A lot of my friends who live in the East said that the westies are like alien to them HAHA! Jurong East is said to be Orchard of the west. Jurong West (Pioneer/Boon Lay MRT) is more of a chill area. There's also a 36km trail linking from Jurong Lake Garden (Lakeside/ Chinese Garden) to Coney Island (Punggol). If you are interested, you can visit Pulau NTU too! Enjoy!

comment: またまたすごい食べましたね。帰る時はワンサイズ大きくなるんじゃないですか？タイ料理は香辛料とか日本ではあまり使わない物を使うので癖があると言うか、個性的になるので好き嫌いが分かれますよね。特に豚の血の料理は沖縄にもソーセージになって有りますが動物の血でも、血には沢山の病原菌が含まれているので自分は気持ち悪くて食べれません。最後のお店は良いですね。海老も大きくて食べ応えがありそうだったし、蟹は渡り蟹かな？身がしっかりしていて卵がホコホコしておいしいですよね？でもジブさん！蟹の手〜笑      頼むから蟹の爪と言って頂戴よ。初めて聞いた。蟹の手🦀ま、良いでしょう😁夜の市場に行くんですね。楽しみにして待ってるけんね。

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Hello, just want to share my experience and thoughts on your idea of home ownership in Singapore. I always believe your first property should always be a property of purpose, not investment. if it serves your purpose and your parthners, its will be the best buy the two of you will appreciate. If the value of your purposeful property increase, its a bonus. if it doesn't, it has served you well nonetheless. On your mother-in-laws perspective on her HDB and how she can make 2 times the profit. To be honest, her flat would most likely be mostly paid in CPF funds. which means when she sells it, most of the profits will return to CPF as well. And the compounded interest when she used her CPF to buy her HDB will be compounded on a 2.6% per year. If i would make a calculated guess, she bought her flat at 160,000SGD, that would be roughly 20 to 25 years ago? so after the interest that she has to pay back cpf and the profits that has to be returned to cpf base on how many percentage of cpf she used to pay her flat. how much cash can she profit? and even if she does liquidate her flat, where is she going to stay? to buy back the the same flat at the same town she stays, is there still going to be a profit at all? so technically, your mother in laws flat is a purpose property. she has to have a place to stay. So in short, investing in Singapore for a HDB flat is most likely for a purpose, not so much an investment. maybe after your HDB purchase down the road, u can consider getting a place in Japan as an investment property. and then its purely for speculation and for investment. hope this helps you make a decision!

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:
Hey Ghib i think this all boils down to Pros and Cons as well as thinking about what you and your wife want in the future.



Apart from finance, I think a more important factor would be the environment if you are planning to raise a family.There are a lot of things Singapore has that Japan doesn't, Racial diversity (my opinion, I think its very eye-opening), No natural disasters, English as a very globalized and opportunistic language, Many opportunities to travel around SEA and Australia due to close proximity, Convenience (Japan has this in cities but not rural).

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:
Hi Ghib, Singaporeans are usually filial and want to live near their parents in Singapore. 
Don't think about investment value. A happy wife is a happy marriage. 
Invest in a happy marriage =)

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:
investment?
If you want to rent, where are you going to live? If want to get two properties, then rent one out, then you'll have to earn loads of money to buy the 2nd property and only to rent out for how much per month? LOL

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Ghib san. The older generation Singaporeans have this general misconception that housing is a sure profit purchase. It was mostly profitable for them because it used to be cheap. In between a few decades of economic growth and inflation, values have risen many times. Housing is also used and promoted as the vessel for retirement and prices were thrown to open market values even for HDB. The market value of a property is no longer growing at that rate any more, rental yields have plunged and stayed low even if you plan to buy and rent out.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Ghib san, we have some commonalities and I feel I should give some input here. I myself was born in Japan and lived there a long time, I had some great times there but was always considered a gaijin due to my appearance. I also have a Singaporean wife, I did ask her out of interest, how she would feel living in Japan. Her concern was how she could integrate into Japanese society as an ethnic Chinese, and whether she would be accepted. Your wife may have the same concerns, better talk with her and realise that it may be harder on her than it would be for a Japanese American to integrate there.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:
Hello and thanks for your video! Hope you will read my comment, even if it might be a bit long:
1. don't ask the mother of your wife for advice, as she will definitely tell you to buy in Singapore and not in Japan, because she wants her daughter to still live close to her, of course! 
2. also don't compare the price the mother paid for her house in the past with how much a house costs now. Of course in the past, when Singapore wasn't that developed, houses would have been cheap, and now because the country grew so much, they became so expensive! That's why old landlords now can get really nice money on houses they bought a long time ago.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Ghib-san, if you intent to live in Singapore for at least 5 years, then I will recommend that you buy a flat in Singapore. I hear your worries, that you are afraid that your property may loses value as you live in it. But you have to consider that the government have very tight control over the housing supply in Singapore. Furthermore, a very significant portion of Singaporean's asset are locked in housing. So the government will do its utmost to maintain the pricing of housing to be stable. It might not increase in value by 2 or 3X like before, but as long as there is still at least 40 - 50% of the lease left, it will not decrease in value. If the value of housing decrease in value even before the lease reach the 50% mark, there will be huge public anger and trouble everywhere. The government will simply build less and control the value of flats through controlling the supply.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: ユーチューブはどこでもできると言っても拠点をどこにするかはとても重要。日本でもグルメや旅行はできるけどこのチャンネルを好きなファンにそれがうけるかどうかも重要。あと奥様が日本の生活、文化は疲れると思う。女性は女親が近い方が頼れるし安心です。奥様のご両親と上手くいっているから後5年そこに住まわせてもらって新築を買った方が99年なら子供もしばらく住めるしね。高い買い物だから迷うよね💦

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: My recommendation is buy a house in Singapore. Since your wife already has a stable job in Singapore it is less troublesome. Also dont have that thinking that buying a flat will sure be a profit because thats older times where people bought it at cheap, now is different. I think it will also have to depend on your budget but other than the house, the cost of living in SG is quite affordable. If you decide to have a kid in Singapore, school fees will be quite cheap as they are mostly subsidised by the gov.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: The 2 areas that you are looking at are expensive for the exact reasons you like it for. It's their central location. It would be better if you gave yourself a budget and keep an open mind when it comes to the location. As long as you get a place near transport nodes, you'll be fine. Unless you get a BTO, don't think about crazy profits or "kueh kueh" money.....LOL

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Bro hope you didn’t miss the fine print at the bottom of your marriage certificate that say “Happy wife happy life”

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: HDB flat is simply just for living, not an investment. Resale flats have some other hidden costs other than the selling price stated. Singaporeans are usually risk adverse and not adventurous. You can look at many of the youtube channels where Japanese men have foreign wives (not Singaporean). They are living happily in Japan as they are willing to learn, adapt and appreciate the lifestyle and culture of Japan. The bank's interest rates for housing loans in Japan are currently pretty low too.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Hi Ghib! I think as a young couple, you and your wife should really consider getting BTO in a young estate. Amenities will be newer/better maintained, and of course the property will be a lot more affordable than the resale flats in the mature estates you’ve been searching in - some of those areas are like the Tokyo equivalent here! The wait may seem a bit long, but like what some have mentioned in the comments, you can keep a lookout for sale of balance flats from HDB, or use the wait to save up for renovations. Most importantly, you and your wife need to consider long-term plans for your family - that will be the deciding factor for where to settle down in. I’m also in the midst of finding a property so I empathise with your home search… All the best!

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: What many of the older HDB owners don’t realise is that if they do sell their old flats and make 2 or 3 times profit, they still need to buy another flat to stay in! Unless they downgrade substantially, they won’t have much of their profit left.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Ghib San, aim for those fast building BTO like those in tengah. Build time approx 3yr from application date. While u get all  the paper work and processes done, it would be only 2yr for your flat to arrive on a subsidised selling price. Grants would be available to help you further financially as well. Meanwhile can save up, live on with your in laws and make more content for us! Thank you!

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: You can try looking in area like Bukit Panjang, which has the Downtown Line that makes travelling to Town rather fast. On top of that, can take a short LRT/bus ride to get to the Red Line (CCK) which is a few stops away from the Green Line. And from Bukit Panjang DTL, take a few stops and you can get to the Circle Line. There's even bus interchange in Bukit Panjang and has a couple of bus around that area which goes straight to Orchard. Two shopping malls there, three if you include Lot One.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:

I do think we're getting ripped off in Singapore compared to back in the 80s.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: I would do what my wife wants me to do 😁Seriously, this is a big decision for both of you to make together. There are lots of factors, some financial, some not. The non-financial issues may be more relevant. Where are you both happier to live?

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Bro, the places you browsed are expensive areas, perhaps you should consider a place further away from the central. There are still many places with facilities and necessities around, except town. As long as you are near to main MRT lines, that is good

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: tbh you mentioned the 5 year wait for bto is long, but if you think about it, time flies really fast. Just like how youve been living in sg for is it 2 years? so you can 1) consider bto and continuing living with your in laws while waiting for it (which thats what some ppl do here, part of saving cost too), else 2) continue living with your in laws hahahah or 3) buy leftover bto units which is same price as bto but without the wait cos its already done as sometimes some units doesnt sell 4) buy resale which as you noticed its expensive because properties worth do increase over years, esp the bigger the unit and depending on how great its condition is and its location, near to mrt, any sch nearby...etc. Side note, toa payoh is considered tho an old estate, but bustling and central location with a bus interchage, thus expensive. Holland v is one of the places where the rich live THATS WHY ITS EX hahahha. If you really want affordable prices you might wanna consider areas not are not central and slightly further... maybe you shld interview your wife, get her opinions and knowledge too! heheh

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: It depends on where you plan to live on the long-term. For me, I would move to Japan because the schools do teach english. The downside is, you might miss the food here because I already started to miss bak kut teh and economic rice on like day 3 of my vacation in Japan, and I was there for two weeks

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore

Everyone has given precious advice, but I just want to add, you should think about your future and what you really want to do. Which place is the best place to live in for you to be happy? Your future and how you build your life is important too. From there, you will know whether a flat in Singapore or a house in Japan is the best choice for you and your wife.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment:
Get Balance Flat. They are new flat direct from HDB. Just that during bto they were not taken. U can get them at a very reasonable price and you don't need to wait many years. I think they're open to public every quarterly or half yearly.
Toa Payoh is a great location but most of the resale flats are very very old. Not advisable.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: I had my reservations when you said you were getting a house in SG and you said it was 'cheap'. response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Resale prices are just crazy as almost all sellers mark up for profits.  May want to try balanced flats (I got mine this way) or BTO for investment purpose in a long run.  My friend relocated overseas and has been collecting rental from their HDB as an additional income.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: If you're okay with slight travel, the prices of houses dip when you start approaching the west. Take for example Choa Chu Kang, Bukit Panjang, Woodlands, Bukit Batok, Bukit Gombak, etc. The average 4-room house here for resale is around $360K. Those areas I've mentioned are pretty accessible to the rest of Singapore as well. Considering that there is the upcoming Jurong Region Line, Downtown Line and Thompson East Coast line. Which are all extremely good to bring you around Singapore.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore
comment: Ghib-san, I would suggest you have a deep discussion with your wife on where you want to stay as a couple. Especially what your wife is going to do if you both move to Japan. As you've said, as a YouTuber, you can work anywhere in the world. But can your wife get a job in Japan? Or would she want to be a stay-home wife in Japan? Can your YouTube income support both of you in Japan, plus afford your house in Japan? Look at all the pros and cons of living in both places, then move forward from there.

response_to: Maybe I Shouldn't Buy a House in Singapore

response_to: Why I Chose to Live and Buy a House in Singapore Over Japan
comment: Hello Ghib san I’m a big fan of your VLOG! 😁 The CPF contribution for Singaporean/PR is actually 20% from employee and 17% from employer up to a max cap of S$6k gross monthly salary. So if your monthly salary is $6k, the total CPF contribution will be 37% of $6k which is $2220 to CPF account, and net salary of $4.8k to employee pocket 😅

response_to: Why I Chose to Live and Buy a House in Singapore Over Japan
comment: You're making me want to live in Singapore. I lived in Japan for 7 years and returned to the states in 2018 since my father was ill. He's okay now, though but has to receive treatments for his kidneys and also had to have heart surgery.  I was around during the Tsunami/earthquake thing in 2011. We lost power and water.  I lived in the Tohoku region from 2010 - 2011, 2012 - 2015.   I moved to Tokyo in 2015 and left in 2018.  Tokyo wore me out and wasn't good for my mental health and I was terribly overworked and the higher cost of living didn't help either for the amount of pay I was getting as living in Yamagata-ken, it was easier to pay for my medications, rent, and foods...Tokyo, not so much...but in some ways I do miss Japan since I was over there so long...even Tokyo. I got so used of the earthquakes, it got to the point where I didn't even notice them and the rocking would help me sleep, which is ironic since I come from an area of the US where earthquakes are incredibly rare (east coast). lol

comment:
Congratulations Ghib🥳🎊🎉

Food for Thought: Many Singaporeans love Japanese culture, food and even. visiting Japan for vacation. However many of us don’t always know where best to go or what best to eat and do for the real experience. The fact that most Japanese websites don’t translate well to English certainly doesn’t help. Perhaps you can consider doing a Japan travel-guide reviewing and recommending hotels, places of interest and restaurants. I believe many of your existing viewers would appreciate an insight by a true blue Japanese like you. It could also be helpful to viewers in culturally-similar neighbouring countries like Malaysia and Indonesia. If you are looking to increase your viewership and subscribers, these other two countries are are a even bigger market.

response_to: Visiting the Craziest Condo in Singapore | The "Jenga" Interlace Condo🇸🇬
comment: My friend lives here and I've been to her house so many times. I didn't even know it was such a unique place, I just saw the buildings and was like "oh you have a cool condo area" xD She has access to part of the roof and she holds parties there because the space is gigantic and open. And it seems private but you can sit on like the roof and look at every apartment and it's not so private cuz you can just look inside cuz they're so near 😂😂 The atmosphere is super nice though, Singapore our HDB and buildings are designed to let maximum airflow go through the layout. Same with the condo. It's very windy and atmospheric, and when you sit on the roof and you hear the water from the pool nearby and look at the sky and the apartments around you, it's a very modern but dreamy atmosphere. IDK how to explain it 😂 Anyway glad you're having fun exploring our tiny country! I'm looking forward to each one of your videos!

comment:
Since you have intention to revisit the area for food blog, so I thought to recommend a few I feel which I think not bad. 
"Poh Cheu", they are famous for this snack call "ang ku kueh" which means red tortoise cake. The skin is made with glutinous rice flour, dyed in red color. There are many choice of different fillings inside; the traditional ones are peanuts and mung bean. Note; the skin is sticky, so don't hold it with tissue paper, else you be eating the tissue paper.

response_to: Visiting the Craziest Condo in Singapore | The "Jenga" Interlace Condo🇸🇬
comment: Hey Ghib Ojisan, if you're going back to take some footage of food for your travel channel, try the prawn noodles in the middle row The Old Stall Hokkien Street Famous Prawn Noodle. Another prawn noodle shop at the row nearest to the road is run by a young hawker, Ming's Prawn Noodle. Doesn't have the strongest or umami-packed broth but the prawns he uses are plump, fresh, and sweet. Avocado juice from Mr Avocado as some others have mentioned, only opens at noon. Peak times are during weekdays lunch hour. Crowd usually dies down at around 1.15-1.30pm or you can go early at around 11. Hokkien Street Prawn noodles usually sells out by 2pm. Another nearby place for great food is ABC Brickworks Food Center, its around a 10min and its across a street to Alexandra Food Village

response_to: Can You Believe This is Singapore?🇸🇬Changi Village🌴
comment: A lot of people got mixed up after the renovation few years ago at Changi hawker centre when all the food stalls were re-shuffled. The original famous nasi lemak is International Nasi Lemak which used to occupy the unit which Mizzy is occupying now. International Nasi lemak is now at the first row facing the bus interchange.  Goes to show some people just queue blindly and they can't tell the difference in taste.  Go to the first row facing the bus interchange and look for the sign board "International Muslim Food Stall Nasi Lemak".

comment: I love the beach at Changi Village. Even more so than the one at East Coast Park. It’s probably the last natural beach left in Singapore. Most of our coastlines underwent land reclamation so the beaches aren’t naturally formed ones anymore.

response_to: Can You Believe This is Singapore?🇸🇬Changi Village🌴
comment: The area is also know to be haunted by the screams and cries for help of the civilians executed by Japanese soldiers.  Rumour has it that there is haunting by an angry Japanese soldier who thinks he is still at war.  You may want to go at night to see if you can hear or feel anything. If you see the Japanese soldier let him know that the war is over and he should go back home.

comment: hmm If I am not wrong, the famous stall in the earlier days was "International Muslim Food Stall Nasi Lemak". As for those deep fried small fish, we call it "ikan bilis". A basic nasi lemak is usually about the nice fragrance rice, crispy ikan bilis, sambal chili and a small slice of omelette. Items like chicken wings, fishcake, otak came in later days when people no longer eat it just a simple fast meal. By the way, I notice Ghib san is a fan of sugarcane juice ya. 😀

response_to: 日本人のぼくが海外で受けた差別の話をします【シンガポール編】
comment: 興味深いですね😀私はヨーロッパ在住です。人種差別‥とはまた少々違うのですかねえ?変な偏見や誤解を受けたことがあります。よく、現地の爺さんたち(大体60後半から70代くらいのジジイ)に声をかけられパートナーになって欲しいやら、ひどいのはお金をあげるから一晩どうか？とかよく聞かれました。アジア人＝中国人または東南アジア、とアジアを一つの国、一つの言語を思ってるヨーロッパ人って未だにけっこういます。だから「中国から来たんでしょ」とか出稼ぎに来てるとか勝手に思われます笑。日本人だからっていう差別は受けたことないし、変態ジジイ達以外の人達は基本みんな優しく接してくれます。悲しいことですが、こちらでは偽装結婚とか違法労働をしてるアジア人もいるのが現実で、その影響か同じ見た目の私も、そう思われてしまいがちです。今は年もとってオバちゃんになりファッ○オフ🖕とかのも使いこなせるようになったので笑、そんなに嫌な事いうジジイは会わなくなりましたが😏

comment: 私が乗り継ぎでシンガポールで2泊した時、ケーブルに乗ってbird park に一人で行ったのですが、Tshirtにペンキが付いてしまったので近くの係りの人に助けを頼みました。日本人なのと聞いて来るのでそうだと答えると、そばに居たお客さん達が一斉に振り向きニコニコ笑いかけてくるのでびっくりしました。日本人は珍しかったのか、裕福な国の人と思われたのか、その後もその人が日本人だと他の人達に言い回り、みんな私の顔を見ることが!ありました。そして親切にペンキをおとしてくれたのです。その時は今の様な近代的な街じゃなくて、ある街角は倒れそうな古い家もたくさんあり、暑くて冷房もなく、すっごく暑かった。でも屋台のお店は安くて美味しかった。30年以上前だったけどね。懐かしい!

atas        = up / high-class (Malay, if I am correct) 

swee       = nice / pretty (Hokkien) 

hao lian   = show off    (Hokkien)

response_to: Reacting to Indecipherable Comments on Singapore's Online Forum🤯
comment: Swee Swee very hard to explain. “Swee” sometimes used as an exclamation of NICE, or Beautiful. Like if you’re watching Football and they score a beautiful goal, you can exclaim “SWEE!”. Swee Swee is used to describe somewhat  “everything going beautifully as planned”. When they say “people think living in Singapore it’s all Swee Swee” means “people think living in Singapore is very easy life”

response_to: 10 Things I Hate About Singapore
comment: I’m Singaporean and I love this! Though I should add that I love the 5am bird. In fact when I was younger, the bird would be my natural alarm clock. School starts at 7.30 so I would need to get up around 5.30am to prepare for school. The bird’s call was timely in that sense. Nowadays, the birds don’t call as loudly. The small “forest” that used to be around my home were cut down to make way for more blocks of flats. I no longer hear these birds as often, so when I do, it makes me happy, and reminds me of my childhood.

response_to: This is Singapore Without Makeup. Japanese Exploring Local Area of Singapore[cc]
comment: I can see you were delighted to talk to that ‘uncle’ in the coffee shop who spoke some Japanese terms, will surely go over and talk to you if I see you on the street. We Singaporean find the Japanese very friendly but they are very afraid to talk to the locals. There are Japanese family staying in our condominium but they mostly keep to themselves. I befriended a Japanese housewife who stay in my condo and we occasionally chatted as we both walked our dog at night , but she has a son who is about 12 that ran away whenever he sees me, I was puzzled ! Not sure if I had spoken to him in English a couple of times and that stressed him out!? 😂 Anyway hope you guys talk to us more often in order to know more local stuff. Cheers

response_to: Typical Reactions of Singaporeans Visiting Japan the 1st Time🇯🇵
comment: Man, I really really miss Japan 😭One weird thing that I noticed was that service staff were really nice, but a lot of the people on the streets were kinda rude, and always gave us dirty looks even though I don't think we were doing anything wrong :/ But maybe that was just in the city areas.

response_to: Typical Reactions of Singaporeans Visiting Japan the 1st Time🇯🇵
comment: My culture shock was the extent of politeness the Japanese have. I mean I knew the Japanese are very polite but to experience it first hand in Osaka still shocked me haha. I was in a clothing store, a relatively older lady and I crossed paths between clothes racks. She stopped and said sumimasen and gestured for me to go ahead. I am easily one generation younger or more and she gave way to me. I think I was so surprised that I forgot to say sorry too, luckily I remembered to say thank you instead.

response_to: Typical Reactions of Singaporeans Visiting Japan the 1st Time🇯🇵
comment: Hey Ghib-san. This is one of my favourite videos of yours. I laughed out so loudly at the beginning of the video. Truly entertaining to watch your skits. Love them. Agree with the point on convenience stores - can’t get enough of them every time. I will visit it daily and still find so many food to try in there. And you can get almost anything. Same goes for Taiwan’s 7-11. And definitely love the train rides in Tokyo (during non peak hours). There are only a few people and it is so so peaceful. When I’m back in Singapore, I can notice the stark difference between our trains and Japan’s in terms of noise level. One more thing - onsen. That is the top to-do thing in Japan. Edit: and also warm toilet seats during winter!

response_to: Typical Reactions of Singaporeans Visiting Japan the 1st Time🇯🇵
comment: Wanna share a culture shock during my first trip in Japan haha! I went with a group of friends, there were 2 females (my friend and I) and 3 male friends, and on our second day in Tokyo we were rushing to get onto the morning train. As it was our first time, we didn't know anything about the female cabin hahaha! So all five of us rushed into the female cabin, and actually delighted that we caught the train in time. Suddenly the girls in the train started laughing at us... then we looked around and realized the 'Female Cabin' sticker. My male friends were so shock their faces went red hahahaha.

response_to: The Best Hawker Centre in Singapore?? Bedok 85🇸🇬
comment: Hiiii Ghib-san, I will like to recommend you go back to Bedok 85 at night. Bedok 85 Hawker Centre is known to be a supper spot! It is open in the morning to service the older folk and the nearby residents, but night time is the magical time to go. The place is packed with Singaporeans from different parts of Singapore, they all drive here for food.

response_to: The Best Hawker Centre in Singapore?? Bedok 85🇸🇬
comment: People go to Bedok 85 hawker centre for dinner or supper as the stalls open till late at night. An alternative place nearby is Bedok 511 hawker centre. Both places sell same dinner and supper food such as soup Bak Chor Mee (they specialise in the soup version whereas most of the time other places specialise in the dry version), BBQ chicken wings, satay, BBQ sambal stingray and fried oyster.

response_to: Trying Singapore's Craziest Cuisine🇸🇬
comment:
Hey Ghib,  "wah lau eh" is actually a negative thing. 
For example: "wah lau eh! why you like this?! "
Means that the person is causing you trouble or putting you in a difficult position.
The way you were saying "wah lau eh" when looking at the frogs and the cooking process can been misunderstood as you giving a negative remark/sound to whatever you were observing.

辛坊治郎さんが「ユーチューブのチャンネル作って外国に頻繁に出掛ける様になって分かった事。日本は物価が安い」と言っていました。
世界はここ数年間好景気を迎えていましたから大抵の外国ではそれに伴って物価も上がっていたのでしょう。しかし日本での物価上昇は限定されていて政府が「これ位にはしたいね」という2％も達成できません。（それでも民主党政権時と比べれば少し上がっていますが…）

response_to: シンガポールのカルチャーショックTOP10！日本人のぼくが3ヶ月住んで感じたこと
comment: シンガポール人です〜シンガポールへようこそ！マレー系な人はマレーシア語ではなくてマレー語を話していますよ。Singlish は外国人にとって変わった英語ですね。実は中国語、中国の方言、マレー語とタミル語を混ぜました英語です。Singlish が嫌い人もあるけど、私はSinglishが面白いと思います。例えば、英語で、「も、食べましたか」と聞きたい時、”have you already had your lunch?” とかを言いますね。Singlish で、ただ “makan already?” で終わります。makan はマレー語で「食べる/食べ物」です。この動画はとても面白かったです。I hope you’ll enjoy your stay here in Singapore! ☺️

response_to: Perhaps The Funniest Video I've Ever Made
comment: Aiyoh.... both of you very naughty ah.. 😒😘😂. The expression on the faces, I was laughing fm the beginning till the end of the video🤣🤣!! The part, the 2nd man said he's an amateur philosopher n you said wah lau/ walau, think you hv used this incorrectly.  You can say wa seh. I notice the same in your other videos (not quite correct, cannot anyhow walau one). Walau is used to express disbelief/ skepticism or cynicism. It's more of a negative comment but without bad intention. Sometimes it's also used when a person is annoyed or irritated. Example my friend msg me at the last minute to say that she will be late by half an hour. In this case, I can use walau to express disbelief (that she's going to keep me waiting for so long) as well as irritation/ anger w. her. Hope this helps to clarify usage a bit...✌️🤗?? Back to your video, this time the video is hilarious n both you and your MIL are belly cute/ kawaii ne 可爱 😂😘🤣！

response_to: I Did NOT Expect to See This in a Super Developed Country | Pasir Ris, Singapore🇸🇬
comment: Singaporeans are actually pretty shy like in Japan, culture-wise. We don't smile or greet one another if we don't already know each other, and we don't strike up conversations with strangers - it's probably considered weird, and it would put people on their guard if it happens without a basis for conversation. However, we are very friendly to tourists and people from overseas, especially those who we can tell appreciate our culture. That's probably why you get a lot of love from us locals. It comes from being a small country in the big world stage, so we're really flattered to be recognised/appreciated.
