response_to: Japanese Guy Learns Chinese! Teacher: Singaporean Mom🇸🇬🤷‍♀️
comment: Good job! Just a note that Hokkien, Teochew, Cantonese etc. are not Chinese "dialects"; they are full Chinese languages that are actually older and richer than Mandarin. Interestingly there are some Hokkien words that bear some resemblance to Nihongo. For example, the number five is "gor" in Hokkien, which is similar to "go" in Nihongo; six is "lahk" which could resemble "roku". Then there is "muah chee" which refers to the sticky rice cake that is of course remarkably similar to "mochi".

response_to: 🎖️World War 2 Survivor Opened This Shop in Singapore🇸🇬 Balestier
comment: Glad you visited Balestier.  When I was a child, my parents used to bring me to this spectacle shop.  And buy coffee powder from the shop beside it. Balestier is named after America's first consul to Singapore. Balestier used to have a lot of sugarcane and rattan plantations.  You can also find other heritage sites like the Balestier market and the Tua Pek Kong temple.  Balestier used to have the old Shaw cinema and Rex theatre.  I spent many a childhood days there.  Do you know that one side of Balestier road has many side streets with Burmese names (Pegu Road, Irrawady Road etc), while the other side are malay names (Jalan Dusun, Jalan Raja Udang) referring to birds and flowers such as Orchard and Deep blue kingfisher?  You should also visit the nearby Whampoa Drive, barely 300 metres away.  It has the traditional bakery (Sin Hon Leong), the VERY famous whampoa drive market and food centre(s) - yes two of them, and the whampoa dragon fountain.  And lastly, I believe the original Loy Kee stall is at whampoa drive food centre, NOT the aircon place you visited.

response_to: 🎖️World War 2 Survivor Opened This Shop in Singapore🇸🇬 Balestier

response_to: 🎖️World War 2 Survivor Opened This Shop in Singapore🇸🇬 Balestier
comment: It's interesting to note that many of the roads around Balestier are named after places and rivers in Burma. Examples include Moulmein Road, Irrawady Road, Rangoon Road and Mandalay Road, just to name four. It's perhaps unsurprising then to find yourself wandering into the compound of a large Burmese temple. All these could suggest some historical links to the Burmese community here.

海外就職するために必要なスキル・資格は？シンガポール現地採用が答える！
comment:
初めてコメントさせて頂きます。長文です。
10数年シンガポールに住んでいます。
大卒やスキル等も必要ですが、私はやる気と忍耐も必要だと思います。海外では日本では無いような事が多々有ります。それを乗り切れる忍耐力が必要になってくると思います。私も全く英語が出来ない状態で就職し他のスタッフから笑われながら、ケンカしながら現地スタッフと接し英語を勉強しました。

今日も貴重なお話しありがとうございました🎵

response_to: 【異世界】イッテQ!で有名になった『ウズベキスタン』に行ってきた！
comment:
5:53より
　あのタワーはウズベキスタンのタシュケントタワーと言い、1984(5)年に完成した高さ375mのラジオ・テレビ塔だそうです。建設当時は世界第4位の高さで、ジブリおじさんが仰ったように中央アジアで一番高い建造物だそうです。また、入場料金はよく分からなかったのですが入場するにはパスポートを見せないといけなくて、しかも撮影不可らしいです。あそこでジブリおじさんが行かなかったのは正解かなぁと思います。

comment:

response_to: 海外ノマドワーカーの一日に密着！〜シンガポール編〜
comment: 決して悪い意味じゃないけど、ノマドって結構孤独な仕事だと思う。一日中動画編集や記事書きしてて下手したら朝から晩まで人と話すことなく終わりそう。それ以外は息抜きするか食事。その繰り返し。事務所に所属していたらミーティングで人と会うこともあるだろうけど、個人でやってればかなり孤独を感じる仕事だと思う。それがあっていれば全然いいけどね！うまく友達と会ったり、人との交流を入れたりしながらやれば最高の仕事になり得ると思う。頑張ってね！

response_to: Visiting a Ghost Town in Asia's Richest Country | Woodlands🇸🇬
comment: @Gjib Ojisan, appreciate it that someone is exploring somewhere outside of the city central, but it seems wrong to call the old woodlands central a ghost town. Although the cinema has been closed for a long time, the area had always been bustling up till 2017, when it was announced that the area would be closed down, and the land used to build an extension of the woodlands check. It was due to this initiative that stalls were closed down, and even the hawker centre was moved to the new marsiling mall. So I would hope that it could be clarified, that the area and this so called “ghost town” was never “abandoned” but was being closed to carry out new plans.

response_to: Visiting a Ghost Town in Asia's Richest Country | Woodlands🇸🇬

response_to: Japanese Attempts to Cook Iconic Singaporean Dish🇸🇬
comment: Thank you Ghib for trying to build a bridge between Singapore & Japan. I had first saw there was a post on facebook saying that there was a Japanese Youtuber who had made a video on Yishun. I was curious. After I had watch your video with your thoughts on it. I had found out that I had really enjoy your vlog. From then I was looking forward to your videos on your adventures around Singapore. It had made me feel like I am walking and taking part in your adventure discovering parts of Singapore through your eyes that I had never knew.  You deserve this from the humble videos that you have shown us. To let us see a different side of Singapore that we singaporean have known. Letting  us discovering new destinations around Singapore, from trying out our local food & reccomending the foods to your other viewers from different countries about singapore heartland foods. Another side of singapore that locals & tourists to come and enjoy. Because it's not everyday you will be seeing tourists from other countries try out our coffee shops foods. Most of the time the tourists will be at town or the top famous  destinations in Singapore. And sometimes I myself as a local will be like. Wow. How come I had not discover this place the food. Or like trying out new things that I don't usually do. Thank you once again for coming to our shores of Singapore & more making our lives more interesting. PS: I am from yishun. Hahahaha. Keep up the good work! I really like the new concept content on your video during this circuit breaker period. It has shown that you have really appreciated and interacting with your viewers. 👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍

response_to: Japanese Attempts to Cook Iconic Singaporean Dish🇸🇬
comment: Sorry to say but Song Fa adds MSG. They have retail packs and MSG is in the ingredient list. It's really unnecessary with good ingredients and simmered low and slow. Not difficult to make at home. Oou, chicken feet are rich in collagen but you should have snipped off the nails. Well, I made the same mistake when I first made chicken broth at home. To get rid of the gamey smell and impurities, place meat in room temperature water, bring a boil for 5 minute. Remove and rinse well in running water. Place meat in fresh water with spice pouches and bring to a boil and then simmer for one hour or longer. Good job on your maiden attempt.

comment:
シンガポール人です 😄

For the locals, there’s no 飲み会. Most of us don’t drink a lot as alcohol is super costly so as for me, I only drink once a month or during special occasions. Many would rather chill at a cafe with friends (perspective from a 20s), catch a movie with a partner, jogging around the city, or spend time with family and strolling at the park than getting wasted with colleagues outside.

Sinar Pagi is expensive and the queues are always long (on weekends you’d be waiting in line for 20 mins or less depending on the volume).

Also if you’re eating nasi padang (any stall) at geylang serai, you’ll definitely pay more than $5. Tasty? That’s subjective, but I enjoy it once in awhile.

response_to: YouTubeがんばりすぎて鬱（うつ）になりかけた話をしたいと思う｜症状と克服方法
comment: 当方、日本で医師をしており、心療内科もかじっている者です。ジブおじは、専門的には「適応障害」という状態であったと考えられます。適応障害に関しては、休息が何より一番効果的です。つまり、シャットダウンというのは、１番良い方法です。うつの人には頑張れという言葉は逆効果ですので、言いません。今後もマイペースに自由にやってくださいね。

comment:
俺、来週50歳になります。
もうこの年になると焦ったり不安になることなんてほとんどないですよ。
人生、いろいろ楽しめる（悲しいことや辛いことも含めて）のって若いときだけだと思います。

response_to: YouTubeがんばりすぎて鬱（うつ）になりかけた話をしたいと思う｜症状と克服方法
comment: 私はシンガポールの教育制度で鬱になりました。自殺したい気持ちが一二年も続いていて、そんな自分を救いたくて今こうして日本にいます。ジブおじさんの気持ちを完全に理解出来る、と言いたい訳では無いですが、こうして動画にして、視聴者さんと向き合って、このような悩みを抱える視聴者に自分の気持ちを発信することでより多くの人が救えるのではないかと思いました。働き方においても、生き方においてもおそらく私達はジブおじから色々刺激を受けていると思うので、数字も大事ですが、形がない影響力もあることを、この場をお借りして伝えておきたいです。

comment: Hi Ghib, yes our "Kiasu" culture stems from the ultra-competitive culture and environment in Singapore. Being a "Kiasu" nation has gotten us so far in terms of economy despite being such a tiny country with no natural resources. Don't worry about using the word "Kiasu" as we Singaporeans already embraced this mindset ages ago. 1. 5 mins train ride. Book tickets online.

response_to: 🇲🇾Almost Regretted Crossing the Border to JB, Malaysia
comment: The crowd is quite shocking for a weekday. I dont think it's due to CNY though. An expert level tip for going to JB: the trains may cost a bit more (S$5 one way from SG to Msia, and RM5 from Msia to SG) but it's 1,000,000x more convenient. The immigration clearance is done for both SG and Msia in Singapore before boarding the train, and there are barely any queues. The tickets you buy are for a specific timing, and the trains generally depart and reach on time (travelling time 5mins across the causeway).  For weekdays, it is also much more easier to get train tickets as compared to weekends where you have to camp and be ready to buy on the day that they are released 1 month ahead. You can try it the next time :) JB has a lot of good food too, at a fraction of the price of SG; i can send you some recommendations if you'd like :)

response_to: 🇲🇾Almost Regretted Crossing the Border to JB, Malaysia
comment: you can go to batam indonesia too by ferry at harbourfront ferry terminal

response_to: 🇲🇾Almost Regretted Crossing the Border to JB, Malaysia
comment: The food that you ate is Ayam Geprek (the latest Indonesian Dish from Java provinces) means Smashed/battered Chicken mixed with crushed chilli, garlic, and sometimes peanuts. Served with fried cabbage and usually fried tofu + tempe (soya bean cake), fresh cucumber. And then pour some kecap manis (sweet soy sauce).

comment:
よー! Ghib Oji-san,, don't know if you'll actually read this:

My Social Studies teacher actually talked about Singapore's state right now. Due to the Covid-19, there are fewer foreigners coming to Singapore. This led to many discounts on for locals for several attractions (hence the 50% discount and if I'm not wrong, there are discounts for USS as well). This is to attract the locals to spend, keeping SG's economy from falling. Basically if there aren't foreigners to spend money in SG, SGeans have to spend theirs (to support the economy).

response_to: Say Hi To This Kind Man!🇸🇬 PAYA LEBAR Expedition in Singapore
comment:
Another great video. Yes..you are right, and smarter than a lot of foreigners...just because I think, you took the time to travel to less know areas..
Singapore is not that expensive a country as many foreigners think. It all depends on where in Singapore you are. Food is cheap at the hawker centres and other stuff like clothing too in the outlying areas. I visited Singapore in 2018 expecting prices to be way higher in Canada, but really they are about the same, with hawker centre food being way cheaper than in Canada. I don't think Singapore deserves to be in the World's most expensive city spot. It is quite affordable. Public transport is also very cheap. In Canada, it is 2-3 times higher. Hotel accommodation is also slightly cheaper and much better too for the price you pay. Singaporeans have much to be grateful for but I hear from my friend there that many complain a lot and think the grass is greener overseas. It really is not.

response_to: Say Hi To This Kind Man!🇸🇬 PAYA LEBAR Expedition in Singapore
comment: And you should try Arnold's Fried Chicken in City Plaza (that's the old looking mall you visited near the end of the video). Really good fried spring chicken. Can probably try it for your other channel.

response_to: Say Hi To This Kind Man!🇸🇬 PAYA LEBAR Expedition in Singapore
comment: Hi Ghib san.. if you happen to go to the old shopping center City Plaza, you must give Arnold's chicken a try. They are located on the second floor. To me it is one of the best fried chicken in Singapore. Must try! Hehe.

response_to: Say Hi To This Kind Man!🇸🇬 PAYA LEBAR Expedition in Singapore
comment:
That is a papaya fruit next to the pineapples.

You are pretty brave to wander around the back streets of Geylang haha. Thankfully it's day time. It's a whole different animal at night and some of the old houses are where most of the brothels are situated with other illegal activities too if you are lucky to chance upon. They are frequented by all walks of life, many foreign workers included looking to get some form of 'release'.

response_to: Why I Chose Not To Join Japan's Best YouTube Agency (MCN) | UUUM（ウーム）
comment: アメリカで育った者ですが、今の日本のユーチューブブーム、アメリカの2010年ー2014年辺りにすごく似てます。当時、ほとんどのトップクリエイター達は何かしらのMCNに入っていました。最初は良かったみたいですが、少ししていろんな問題、MCN側の不正、契約の問題、などなどでクリエイター達が離れ始めてほとんど消えました。日本のクリエイター達も同じ道を進んでるみたいなので気をつけてほしいです。じぶおじもこれからがんばってください！

response_to: What's Happening Here? NDP Rehearsal 2020🇸🇬
comment:
The "fireworks" you heard is actually called the "Feu de joie" or in other words "fire of joy".
The fire of joy is shot as a gesture of celebration or victory. In this instance it was shot in celebration for singapore's birthday.
I was part of the Airforce Guard Of Honor last year doing the Fire of joy :D

response_to: What's Happening Here? NDP Rehearsal 2020🇸🇬
comment:
It’s not fireworks, it’s the firing of the soldiers’ rifles (blanks of course) from left to right and right to left in the parade, as a salute.

It is called the feu de joie (fire of joy) in French.

response_to: 国別の幸福度ランキングを見た感想。日本がシンガポールとノルウェーに負ける理由とは
comment:
世界幸福度ランキングを大学で研究しましたが、このランキングの順位が高い＝幸せという考えは短絡すぎます。

まず、このランキングはGDPやら健康寿命など客観的な指標によって構成されています。ちなみに寛容さも正しくは「過去にどれだけチャリティー活動にお金をかけたか」という指標です。なので電車の話のようなニュアンスではありません。

response_to: 国別の幸福度ランキングを見た感想。日本がシンガポールとノルウェーに負ける理由とは
comment: シンガポールは、どちらかといえば、給与の高い人達程幸福をあまり感じておらず、そこそこの人達(3000から5000ドルあたり)のほうが、HDBに住んで、定時で帰り、普段はホーカー、時々レストランで贅沢したりで不満を感じる事がないようです。給与が高い=ストレスがそれだけ多い、残業も増える、高いコンドや車の出費で追われるようになる、といった感じでしょうか。ただ、日本で長年働いたあと、シンガポール移住して思ったのは、日本は物凄く窮屈な社会だという事。色々な事に寛容な社会ではありません。すごく便利だし、色々整っている事には違いないですが、街は美しくなく(清潔ではありますが)、芸能人叩きのニュースばかりで前向きなニュースも少ない。会社は常に周りの人の顔色ばかり伺い、有給も自由に取れない・・。赤ちゃんや老人にもあまり優しくなく、殺伐としています。

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: Make a formal complaint to PropertyGuru and let them follow up with it.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: The best way to win at any negotiation is the ability to walk away from the deal. There will always be better hdb flats for sale.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment:
Ghib San, theses are common negotiating tactics by agents to increase the price. Whether the other buyers are imaginary or real, it is hard to know.

Patience and not being emotionally committed to a nice house is important. The side that is more urgent, or more interested in the sale/purchase will usually lose the negotiating advantage for price. Never say you are in a hurry, and never over express interest in the house. Shop around more and  tell the agent you are also considering other units. The more options you have, the more command you have in the negotiation.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment:
Sounds like a shady deal.
If it hasn't reached MOP, how can they sell or even re negotiate for a new price?

I think the agent should know this before u even start your viewing..

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: Probably it’s imaginary :(( as usual maybe agent doing for the commission like u said :(

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: So sketchy. If the MOP is not fulfilled, the owner CANNOT sell the house. As if HDB would let them. Unless there are extenuating circumstances, like the owner is bankrupt/emigrating/has a serious head injury that renders them stupid enough to list on propertyguru for fun. Therefore, unless it's any of these and they have gotten permission from HDB to sell their property before the MOP is up, the property agent has no biz coming back to you and telling you got people making higher offers. What the fish???

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: U have to be prepared to walk from the deal. If they sense that u love the flat too much, they'll play you.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment:
Ghib, get a agent whom u knew. Ur wife Singaporean maybe she know somebody or fren fren whom u can trust?

Don't rush to buy a house, take your time and i am sure u can find your dream home and most importantly within your budget. Good Luck!

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: Very unethical. As much as you love the flat, I would advise you to stop dealing with this kind of seller. Don't rush into buying a flat. Take your time. It is an investment and you are planning to stay for many years. Walk away if you don't feel right. I would suggest that you find a credible agent to help you. Since your wife and parents-in-law are  Singaporeans, they may have contacts.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment:
So the testing out the waters thing happens at least I know it also happens in Austria sometimes. What definitely should not happen is the agent telling you straight up that they are doing that.
The thing with the other "buyer", if there really is another party interested in the property or not should not matter to you. Figure out for yourself what you are willing to pay for the thing and stick to that and try to negotiate the price, if you don't get it well than thats that you'll find another place. You guys have a place where you can stay atm so don't feel rushed to take the first place you like.

response_to: The Struggles of Buying a House in Singapore😡
comment: Sketchy AF. Normally when an agent is representing the seller. He/She does not reveal the asking price of another buyer as this break the code of ethic and it is not fair. Probably the agent wants to mark up the price to gain an extra profit. PLS check the validity of the Salesperson's Registration Number by going https://www.cea.gov.sg/public-register . Also to test water to find out the price wasted your time for viewing the unit is not ethical and this shatter your hopes .  By right the agent should have factored in the MOP of house, ethnics etc before viewing the house.  You can also look at propertyguru,

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt
comment: This shop sells out by 3pm every day. And certain times of the day like lunch time, there will be a super long queue. 10 years ago they sold like 50 cents each. Now it’s 80 cents. Still very reasonable. But most importantly they taste really good. Quality still consistent throughout the years.

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt
comment: おお、行ってたんですね。そこは密かに昼だけやってるエコノミーライスも絶品で、うちは週に何回か行ってます。その豆沙餅はジップロックに入れて冷凍しとけばレンジでチンして食べれるので、冷凍庫に常にストックしています。ところでそのお婆ちゃん、笑ってるところ初めて見て驚愕！ 英語をしゃべれてさらに驚愕！！！ いつも不機嫌MAXでよく彼女のマイルールに従わない客に中国語で怒鳴ってるんですがｗｗｗ 私も一度怒鳴られましたが、「おお、今日もお婆ちゃん元気だな」と気にならなくなりました。

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt
comment: Ghib, you are so harworking and you seem like a genuine guy. I hope you get more subscribers in the future.

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt
comment: I gave my relatives Loong Fatt tau sar piah together with my wedding invitation in the 1990s. Now my boy is 19 year old, it is still our favorite snack ! Must buy every time we are near this location. Love both the sweet & salty ! Yummy ! Must go there soon ! Please don't close !

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Famous Tau Sar Piah🥧Loong Fatt
comment: In the beginning of your video as you passed the Chinese temple, there is another store called the House of Tau Sa Piah which also has a long history. The difference is that it is completely vegetarian. Vegetarians, vegans and Muslims can try this traditional green bean paste pastry from this store instead. The Loong Fatt is likely not vegetarian as they probably use pork lard in their dough. Other commenters please correct me if I’m wrong. Thanks 😊

comment: Hi Ghib, you should go visit Sungei buloh wetland reserve. It is a fantastic place where you will definetly see a different side of Singapore. You even have a chance of sighting wild crocodiles. The reserve has beautiful mangroves with many unique species that are native to Singapore. The best times to visit Sungei buloh is during the birds migratory season which is from September to march (correct me if I’m wrong). I think you will love the nature reserve Ghib sir. Hope you visit it some day! Ps: I would love it if you commented on this post. Thanks sir!

comment: シンガポールは概ね、マレーシアの物価の3倍。1番理想的なのは、シンガポールで働き、たまに近隣国にプチ贅沢旅行に行くスタイル。マレーシアは、KLでも飛行機や長距離バスで数千円で行ける。マレーシア、タイ、ベトナムで高級ホテルに滞在して安くマッサージにも行ける。逆にマレーシアで働いているとその逆はかなり難しい。

comment: もう15年前になるけど、日本の会社で働いていて「アホだな～」って思っていたのが勤怠管理。ほとんどの会社がそうだと思うけど、通勤の列車が遅れると必ず上長に電話連絡、そして駅で列に並んで遅延証明を貰って乗り継ぎの場合はダッシュして乗り換え。それでも仮にタイムカード打刻が5分遅刻だったとしよう。たったこれだけのために

comment:
大学の卒論で労働生産性をテーマにしたから思うけどホントに日本は生産性が低い、結論づけるの難しかったけどやっぱり国民性ってのが一番だと思う、同調圧力で日本の経済社会は動いてる
でもそのおかげで世界的に見てもとてもルールを守る日本というのがある、震災の時でも列を作るし、財布を落としてもかなりの確率で返ってくるし、でも逆にそのせいで陰湿なイジメとか気疲れするって言う弊害もあると思う

Stick to you budget, as you said. 2. Obtain quotes from a few different companies, and let them outbid each other without revealing who they are competing with. 3. Request to visit some of their ongoing projects that are near completion before you decide. You want to compare the quality of their workmanship. 4. Don't be afraid to ask for more things if they don't want to reduce their prices. 5. Commit everything on paper/contract.

response_to: Visiting the Ancient Town of Singapore! Toa Payoh🇸🇬
comment: Hey Ojisan I live in Toa Payoh. Been living here all my life. Have you visited the old Toa Payoh Park? There is an iconic tower there that has been closed for many years . During 70s to 80s it was a favourite haunt of many Toa Payoh residents. I remember my dad waking me up one early dawn to bring me to the tower to see the 9 planets that were lined up. It was considered a rare phenomenon. Other than the Shuang Lin Monastary (which had been there long before Toa Payoh became a residential town) , a few other old temples, the dragon playground and Toa Payoh Garden, etc there's not much to see unless you're a foodie. :) Must have been a hot day for you. =D

response_to: Visiting the Ancient Town of Singapore! Toa Payoh🇸🇬
comment: Recommend to visit the Whampoa dragon as well. That is a classic although it doesn't sprout water anymore.  Nearby, there are two (yes, not one but two) hawker centres which are famous with good food.  One opens in mornings while the other becomes active from 11am till late evening.  Many good and famous food stalls.  Hoover Rojak (visited frequently by Chow Yun Fatt), Singapore hokkien mee (open in evenings), duck rice/porridge (open till afternoon only) etc.  Too many to choose from.  These are the hawkers centres residents hope will NEVER get onto Michelin lists (so as to keep them relatively accessible and not too busy with tourists).

response_to: Japanese Searching for Flaws at Singapore's TOP Polytechnic | Ngee Ann Poly
comment: In Singapore, after you graduate Secondary school, and get either N Level or O Level certificate, majority of the students get to choose whether you want to take a diploma or an A Level certificate. If you want to specify in a specific field, then a diploma in that field is what they take, and the polytechnics provide this. Polytechnics and ITEs (which is another choice you can go to) focus more on vocational and work skills. That is why the school campus is so big, because in Ngee Ann alone, it is split into (if I'm not wrong), 9 schools. Each school teaching different fields. Eg, Technology, Film, Art, Engineering, Business, Sciences. There are internal shuttle buses to move within the school easier. Many of the teachers too come from the actual industries that they are teaching about.

response_to: Japanese Searching for Flaws at Singapore's TOP Polytechnic | Ngee Ann Poly
comment: There's no so-called best polytechnic in SG..but rather each poly has its credits in offering a wide variety of courses that are recommended for students who wish to pursue pragmatic studies  and gain practical experience before preparing to work in either private or public sectors. Poly students are known to be versatile, resilient,  creative and fun-loving... partly due to their on-the-job (OJT) training that commence in Poly.

comment: 多分シンガポールの教育システムを理解する必要と思います。シンガポールの教育は小学が六年間で、中学は小学の成績によって四年間でも五年間でもあって、これから中学の成績によって高校かポリテクニックに行きます。ポリテクニックは日本の専門学校と似ているもので、いろんな専門を勉強できます

comment:
日本は江戸時代の鎖国時にオランダの言葉が、そして開国した時、英語だけでなくドイツ語・フランス語が流入しました。
それが全て「外来語」という括りでカタカナで日本語化していったので、混乱するんですよね〜。

user: F a e l e i a
comment:
Your "harngnh?" Is even better than our "huh". 

I'm totally stealing it! I could kind of get the delicacy thing but 食べ放題 to viking is a bit.. you can do a singlish skit next time! Haha singaporean slang is difficult to translate but once you get it,  so easy to use. We pride singlish for being able to convey a ton of information from intention, mood and information in as little words as possible, plus it is whatever goes,  as long as you interchange words as you please. I remember having tons of fun mixing japanese into singlish with my friends when I was learning it in uni, and they totally get it! Terrace house (Opening new Doors) the popular j reality series has an example by Maya where she said " Meccha me too!" And she means "that is sooo me too!" To convey she has a common interest with Noah her love interest. In this note, Singlish will totally fit as well, like "walao, that day Bro was meccha late leh, how can like that one, i was so harahetteru that i almost kong ka kiao (dialect: collapse) on the floor leh, ima gui diam(dialect: what time) already still not here,  nani the f"

comment: Platform is made of plat and form. There is no F in Japanese so Fo becomes Ho and an M at the end also does not exist in Japanese. As a result the short form Ho - Mu was born!!

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment: 日本在住のあるアメリカ人が「日本の敬語は、人と壁が作れるから便利」と言ってて、敬語が面倒臭いものでしかなかった私には目から鱗でした。なんでもアメリカでは当たり前に初対面からプライベートにズケズケ入って来る人がいて、なまじ悪い人でもなさそうだから拒めず、面倒だったとのことです。

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment: My number 1 culture shock in Japan.  It was summer,  I travelled to Japan to meet customers,  you need to wear formal,  Japanese formal means the suit,  coat,  tie.  It was too expensive to take taxi,  so need to take train and walk.  Wait that isn't the shock.  The shock is during meeting in Japanese offices and I mean big names like Canon,  Sony etc,  the freaking temperature is 27 or 28 degrees.  Can u imagine summer outside 33 degrees,  you walk to an office you are all wet,  and I walk with my coat off.  Then you are usher into the office for a meeting at 28 degrees,  sweating like a pig.  Lol

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment:
敬語も場合に依りますが相手への愛情に近いかなと思います、僕は嫌いじゃないです、面倒ではありますが(笑)
英語はちょっと、仕方ないなと思います。日本で人生完結できる環境ですし、日本語と英語って言語の相性が悪いです…日本語と英語のバイリンガルって本当に尊敬します。

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment: 日本人はホント良く働くよね。勤勉さがあるからこそ日本ブランドのクオリティーがあるんでしょうけど、皆なんの為に働いてるか時々不思議に思う。旅行する為？家族と良い時間を過ごす為？休日を楽しく過ごす為？日本人は仕事の為に家族も時間も犠牲にしている様に思えてしまう。言い方は悪いかも知れないけど、仕事取ると何も残らなそうな人多いよね… 今のコロナ禍でも、出社するのが正義だみたいに思って胸張って通勤している映像を良く見るよね。もっとおおらかに生きませんか？って感じ。

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment:
Culture shock I received in my four years of living in Japan as a Singaporean: 

1) everyone BUYS water. No one brings water bottles around and like even if they do it's for like hot drinks lol. Everyone justs buys frm vending machine. I miss my water coolers in my singapore schools :( sucks that I have to pay for water in school lol.

response_to: My Culture Shock in Japan | USA & Singapore vs Japan
comment: Being a Canadian that’s born in S’pore, I’ve visited Tokyo briefly on my trips back to S’pore. The 2 things that strikes me most is the meticulous cleanliness of everything - even backstreets and alleys, and the politeness of the sales staff. These two observations have to be personally experienced to be fully appreciated. I’m an avid photographer and would search out off the ordinary local scenes wherever I go, taking me through nooks and corners. Believe me, a photographer’s eyes tend to pickup little details often overlooked by others, and I was just amazed at the cleanliness in Tokyo👍

response_to: Which Chicken Rice is the Best? Collab Stream With STB
comment: That light sauce is what they put over the chicken (usually made of light soya sauce and sesame oil and traditionally some fats and soup from the chicken broth). They separated it so as not to soak the rice and chicken and making everything soggy because you ordered delivery. It is like dashi but like a condiment right before serving. It will make your chicken rice moist and gleaming, but not soggy. A good traditional chicken rice's chicken would have a layer of gelatinized fats under the skin, too. Very difficult to find now as it takes skill and the chickens have to have a certain level of fats (ie. age, etc.). Also, the rice has to be really fragrant (from the fats and other ingredients for fragrance) and not too soft which can still see every grain of rice and not squashed (something like how the rice is of a good sushi).

response_to: I'm About to Give Up Learning Chinese
comment:
Hi Ghib, just wanna help 3:20
When speaking of nouns in repetition, the second character would be emphasized.
So 哥 (would mean older brother), will be 哥哥. 弟 would be 弟弟. 
When nouns that have 2 exact words, the pinyin is different for both characters. For example,  哥, as is would be prononuced as gē. However, when you use 哥哥 the pin yin would be gē ge. That is mostly because native speakers would naturally emphasize the end of 2 identical characters, so as to not sound monotonous.

I have, though, been asked to make tea for clients and I thought it was really weird, but okay, I didn't really think much of it. comment:
Hello Ghib Ojisan. Just to recommend some super nice food to you at Gourmet Paradise, Toa Payoh Interchange.
Take the train to Toa Payoh Station. Once you exit, turn left, go up the escalator. You will see Toastbox and Breaktalk. Walk a few shops from Toastbox along the Interchange, on the left side, you will see the signboard GOURMET PARADISE. The food court is at the basement. You must try the traditional MUAH CHEE at the other far end and the ROJAK at the entrance.

response_to: HUAT AH! Japanese Preparing For Chinese New Year in Singapore🇸🇬
comment: The Chinese New Year tradition in Singapore is same as southern China - oranges, flowers, lion dance. Different from northern China which doesn’t do lion dance, not much flower and no oranges. They boil dumplings which is not a southern tradition. Most Han Chinese were living in the south. Happy new year to you too. May prosperity and good health be yours in abundance.

comment: Hello Ojisan! For CNY, you might want to visit the Istana (where the President of Singapore resides). It's only open to the public on certain days of the year. It'll be open on 26 Jan 2020. If you are lucky, v you might meet madam President herself! Happy New Year!

response_to: My Honest Thoughts on Living in Singapore for 1 Year
comment: Hey Ghib love your videos! Here are some things i would say about japan too: during rush hours in tokyo its almost impossible to board a train. You will be pushed and even stepped on. The person won't even look at you and say sorry. Because it became like a norm. But i feel thats double standard - for a country thats supposed to be so polite, why would you do that and not even say 'excuse me' or sorry. Secondly lets not forget about "Chikans".. Japan is probably the only country where molestation rate is so high that separate 'women only' train carts had to be introduced.. and to make the matters worse, most of the victims just secretly gets molested without raising any voice. Such case in singapore is very rare. Thirdly, when an elderly comes in the train or bus, most people give up their seats in Singapore. It never happens in Japan unless its a special seat. You talked about Japan being clean - i used to think that too but If you go to the back  ally of Shibiya, Shinjuku, Ebisu you will see how crazy it is. Unlike singapore japan doesn't have any trash bins and they expect everyone to carry their own trash. Well many people (especially young ones) doesn't want to do that, so they trash the street and sidewalks. In singapore you don't see it often. And i dont think people are afraid to get a fine, its just that the trash bins are everywhere. You talked about the weather - Japan isnt always cold ..you have summer and also other pleasant seasons when the temperature is just nice. So there is a variety. In singapore its always summer every day of the year ..if you live here for 10 years you may start to miss winter again.  You are right about Conbini and super having good professional service, but then again most frontline staff in Singapore are not really Singaporeans due to pay being low and cost of living being high. In Japan even though there are some foreigners in frontline recently, majority i believe are still Japanese. I feel most Japanese people  don't know how to express themselves well, or say no or have a voice of their own. So they cant really speak their mind which is why they are sometimes following rules blindly. I feel its not very good and needs to change. Frankly you have been very nice about Singaporeans in your video. i think the culture here is unique just like how it is in Japan.

response_to: My Honest Thoughts on Living in Singapore for 1 Year

response_to: My Honest Thoughts on Living in Singapore for 1 Year
comment: Singaporean manners are still ‘work in process”. We’re only 55 years old. Thus, Singapore can never match Japanese maturity. But, I’m sure we’ll continue to improve in this area.

response_to: My Honest Thoughts on Living in Singapore for 1 Year
comment: TBH, I had the intention to dislike this video, because I thought it was going to be another Youtuber trying to be politically correct, saying all the nice things about a country, just because they don't wish to offend anyone, or get de-monetized, etc. But you didn't do that, and as long as they are factual and true, I don't see why anyone should take offence. There are a lot of inconsiderate Singaporeans, but people should also keep in mind that almost half the population in Singapore are not natives, so you cannot guarantee that the bad behavior you happen to encounter is from a local. I have seen my fair share of bad behavior, from Singaporeans and foreigners alike. But all in all you are right on the money, as long as you think of it as the behavior of the people in Singapore, and not the behavior of Singaporeans. And that is also why I really admire the work ethics and etiquette of the Japanese, it may be more stressful, but very highly regarded.

response_to: My Honest Thoughts on Living in Singapore for 1 Year
comment: There are 2 things I've to wholeheartedly agree with you as a Singaporean. The social etiquette (manners) and lack of an appreciation of hygiene and consideration for others. Some people esp elderly aunties can't wait for passengers to get out before they get in (I feel like slapping them!) at MRT. Then those that don;t even say thank you to you for holding the lift door open for them, instead they take their own sweet time to walk to the lift. So fed up with their sense of entitlement, I stop being kind to such idiots. It is also the very reason why some shop assistants don't greet people anymore esp Singaporeans because some among us don't respond ( I'm sure a smile will suffice even if you don't feel like greeting back!). Also while this conoravirus has made some Singaporeans mask themselves when they are sick, I'm sure once this is over, they will continue to cough into the air and spread their flu to innocent persons. I think some selfish Singaporeans need something really deadly to teach them a hard lesson about civic consciousness for others and personal hygiene. Like Minister Chan Chun Seng says of some Singaporeans in the leaked closed door discussion with business owners, these idiots that panic grabbed every damn thing on the shelves are "sia suay" (disgraceful).

response_to: ノルウェーに住んでビックリしたことTOP7！カルチャーショックだらけだった
comment:
路上ライブを見ていて、こちらの動画まで辿り着きました。
私は、1994年のリレハンメルオリンピックの時に、支援会社のスタッフとしてトータル3回2か月程リレハンメルで過ごしました。Ghibli Ojisanの動画を懐かしく拝見しました。私が最も驚いたのは、便器の大きさと小便器の位置の高さでした。小をするのに爪先立って用を足さなければならないのには困りました。現地スタッフと話していて意外だったのは、「実は、ノルウェーとスウェーデンは昔から仲が悪くて互いをバカにする間柄で、丁度日本と韓国のようだ。」と言っていた事です。昔から領土を取ったり取られたりして戦争した(?)のがその背景の様です。Yesの件も驚きでしたね。初めは「エッ、ここでシャックリ？」と思える程でした。最後は自分もしてましたけど。オリンピックの開会式を特等席とも言えるジャンプ台横のタイミング塔で見れたのは、とても良い思い出です。それから、その後日本でAce of Baseというポップス グループに人気が出ましたが、多分私が初めに聴いた日本人だと思います。現地のレコード店に入り、「こっちで人気が出てきてるアーティストは誰？」と聞いてそのカセットテープを買って帰った事があります。もう、25年も前の事です。

現在ノルウェー在住で、明日帰国します。
物価も激高ですけど一般市民の収入も激高ですよ。
パートタイマーの時給NOK100は最低レベルです（出稼ぎ移民）労働賃金は8時間を超えると1.5倍にUP、土日の労働は通常賃金の2倍（21時以降も）になります。純ノルウェー人、正社員の年収は余裕の1000万円超が殆どです。（パートタイマーが8か月労働で年収600万レベルだそうです）

comment:
"Overpriced green onions, overpriced natto"
Yeah, prices were much lower at Donki when they opened their first outlet at Orchard Central. For example, Frugra would cost $5.90-$7.90, now it goes for $9.90-$13.90. Same for other japanese snacks/food items. Donki's first 6 months lived up to it's reputation as a discount chain store, now it feels more like a japanese themed supermarket with similar pricing to CS/NTUC.

comment: Your landlady is very homegrown SG auntie🤭 you can also visit SG museum when it open again, it shows all the picture from the past, even WWII pictures. Each time I travel for holiday, the moment I touched down in our Changi airport I felt so good to be home.

comment: i believe when auntie said 10 cents per day for her schooling is not referring to the school fee but her pocket money.  i was born in the early 70s, when i go to school i was given 30 cents, everyday i only spend 10 cents and saved up the 20 cents. however i do not have piggy bank, so i passed to my grandma she had a box and when my 20 cents accumulate to few dollars, she will used it to buy some goodies for me to eat.

response_to: The Kampong Times in Singapore👩🏻🌴
comment:
What a coincidence, my mum just recently told me about some of her life story in Kampung. This is an funny one for me:
when she was around 15/16 (45years back), she often walk 2 streets down to her richer neighbour's house (they own a few small plantations) to watch TV at night. As mentioned in this video, when a household buys a tv, alot of people will gather outside their house everyday to watch the TV through their window because TVs are considered luxury. My mum say that the sandy roads at night were so dark that if someone were to grab you and pull you to the side and rape you, no one will know.

response_to: Avoiding Tourist Traps in Osaka - My Local Food Recommendation
comment: Like it when you switched between Japanese and English, also adding subtitles when you're speaking in Japanese, it's a free lesson for understanding Japanese. Great that you're also putting SGD in the food you recommend. Look forward to a day hearing Singlish from you, it'll be really interesting.

response_to: Avoiding Tourist Traps in Osaka - My Local Food Recommendation
comment: For someone who lived in Singapore for some time, you must have been too used to finding a rubbish bin almost everywhere... :P I had a holiday in Tokyo few years ago. As it was my first visit to Japan, I was really shocked and impressed the city is so clean despite rarely any rubbish bins around. While in Singapore, areas can be still dirty though rubbish bins are so commonly everywhere. We have a lot of education to catch up with Japan on this.

response_to: Avoiding Tourist Traps in Osaka - My Local Food Recommendation
comment: 10:45 It's like you just had reverse culture shock. www
replies_attracted: View 2 replies from Ghib Ojisan and others

response_to: Avoiding Tourist Traps in Osaka - My Local Food Recommendation
comment: Japan is my favourite holiday destination. Great food and clean air.  Country is safe, places are clean, prices are reasonable and people are considerate of others.  I love its social norms.  People talk softly in public transportation, people  return food trays and clean up tables they used after meals . No trash bins on street because people don't litter and take home their trash for sorting/recycling.  Many good social norms we Singaporeans can learn from.   I take my children to Japan every year for sightseeing and exposing them to good social habits and behaviours.

response_to: Avoiding Tourist Traps in Osaka - My Local Food Recommendation
comment: Ghib-san!!... Awesome videos man!!.. Btw, your reviews on Singapore and its culture and its food are by far the best. I had friends who had seen your vids visiting some food hawkers which were long lost and you found them!. If you must know, some of these food hawkers have been in the business for more than 50 years generations to generations. Sadly after a few years, they've been relocated and some are lost in time. But you have found most of them. Please do more of these videos as it will help the older generations find their long lost childhood favorite food. Not to forget the younger generations too. We here in Singapore have this culture called 'fooding around' Singapore to find good food. Thanks again Ghib-san. Arigato-gozaimasu!!!

response_to: Should you still come to Singapore? UPDATE

伝え忘れたので補足 Forgot to say something important.
Number one priority should be health. If you are traveling with small children or elderlies, I would reconsider the trip. 
Small kids will touch everywhere in public and he/she might get infected from that. And for the elderlies, they have weaker immunity. I do not want to say this because I know a lot of people have planned the trip from so long ago. But health should be the number one priority.

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Popular Nonya Kueh🍰 Tiong Bahru Galicier Pastry
comment:
The green kuih is called Kuih Salat (sah-laat). It's a kuih with glutenous rice with a coconut & pandan jelly on top. It's a pretty popular malay kuih especially during wedding receptions. 

The brown/orange kuih is the same kuih but different variation of one another; a brown sugar or tapioca mixture with coconut & flour (Kueh ubi bingka i believe).

response_to: Foreigner Tries Singapore's Most Popular Nonya Kueh🍰 Tiong Bahru Galicier Pastry
comment:
Singlish : "Okay, can can". Standard English :"Okay, I'll take it". 
Ghib san speaks standard English with an American accent. However, when he talks with Singaporeans, he switches to Singlish. Singaporeans should be able to switch code when speaking to foreigners.

As a guy from PRC living in sg for many years who wash meat and nvr drink tap water, my justifications are as follows:

Why I wash meat is because 1) i afraid that the machines or butcher's knife which cut the meat is not clean, or during the process of packaging whatever gets into contact with the meat is not clean. 2) to get rid of blood. 3) we kick the baskets so we got to wash the meat (jk)

In the old days, meat was prepared from freshly butchered animals in the market. The conditions might not be hygienic. So, its good to wash the meat.

comment: I'm glad our government is using our funds to take care of foreign workers. They played an important part in the development of our country and I will be eternally grateful to them for doing the "dirty work".

response_to: My Bangladeshi Bro Cannot Leave His Dormitory🇧🇩 Semi-Lockdown Day8 Singapore
comment: The initial hygiene problem was due to an abrupt increase of human activity when all the workers (except a portion of essential workers) had to stay in the dormitories at the start of the circuit breaker.  Now the problem has been sorted out as they move workers out to create space n raise cleaning frequency. I am happy that your Bangladesh friend feel safe and well-taken of by our government. And we thank him and his friends for bearing with the isolation for the sake of Singapore people. Grateful.

Sorry! My bad!!!

comment: ジブリおじさん、こんにちは。私は社会人になってからカナダ留学をしたのですが。なかなか快適な…家に恵まれなかった私が最後に出会ったママがいます。仕事から帰ったら、いつも美味しいごはんを作って、待っていてくれました。私たちとお出かけするのも、おしゃべりするのも、テレビ見てごろごろするのも心から楽しんでいた彼女の笑顔を、美味しそうな料理にみんなと語らうロジャーさんを通して思い出しました。
